questions.text: A 14-year-old Asian girl is brought to the physician because of a 6-week history of fatigue. During this period, she has had a 3-kg (6.6-lb) weight loss and intermittent low-grade fevers. She also reports recurrent episodes of pain in her left wrist and right knee. She has no personal history of serious illness. Her aunt has rheumatoid arthritis. The patient appears pale. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F). Examination shows diffuse lymphadenopathy. Oral examination shows several painless oral ulcers. The left wrist and the right knee are swollen and tender to touch. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 10 g/dL, a leukocyte count of 3000/mm3, and a platelet count of 80,000/mm3. Urinalysis shows excessive protein. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anti-citrullinated peptide antibodies are a group of autoantibodies that are highly specific for rheumatoid arthritis (RA). RA may manifest with joint pain, constitutional symptoms, and, in some cases, renal involvement (proteinuria) and pancytopenia. This patient's family history of RA puts her at increased risk of developing this condition. However, her age (RA typically affects middle-aged people) and the presence of oral ulcers and lymphadenopathy make RA an unlikely diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Although nonspecific, the monospot test is often used to support the diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis (IM), a common viral infection seen in adolescents and young children. Patients often present with fever, lymphadenopathy (mainly cervical), and fatigue, which lasts for several weeks, and can develop pancytopenia and joint pain (due to viral arthritis). However, patients with IM often have a preceding sore throat and do not typically develop oral ulcers or renal damage (as suggested by proteinuria), making it an unlikely diagnosis.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's constitutional symptoms and features indicating multisystem involvement (i.e., musculoskeletal, mucocutaneous, hematological, and renal manifestations) raise concern for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Anti-dsDNA antibodies are highly specific for this condition and correlate with disease activity (especially with lupus nephritis). Prevalence of SLE is highest among Asian, African American, and Hispanic population groups in the US. Approximately 20% of patients with SLE have a disease onset in childhood. The classic malar rash that is common in adult SLE patients is not seen in two-thirds of pediatric patients.

Pancytopenia in SLE is typically the result of immune-mediated destruction of mature peripheral cells and/or destruction of precursor cells within the bone marrow.

D) INCORRECT:

Excessive lymphoblasts on a peripheral smear and/or bone marrow aspirate suggests leukemia. The presence of > 20% lymphoblasts in bone marrow is indicative of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), the most common childhood cancer and an important differential diagnosis in this case. ALL can manifest with many of the same systemic findings seen in this child (i.e., lymphadenopathy, fever, weight loss, fatigue) and bone pain. However, swollen joints and proteinuria are not typically seen in ALL, making this diagnosis less likely.

E) INCORRECT:

The presence of Reed-Sternberg cells on lymph node biopsy is diagnostic of Hodgkin lymphoma (HL). HL can manifest in children with chronic fatigue, weight loss, fever, and lymphadenopathy. However, renal involvement rarely occurs in HL and involvement of the joints is not typical, making HL an unlikely diagnosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Pathergy skin testing is used in the diagnosis of Behcet disease, which can manifest with oral ulcers (most commonly), arthritis, renal involvement (hematuria, proteinuria), and fever. However, Behcet disease is uncommon in young children and does not cause lymphadenopathy or pancytopenia. In addition, Behcet disease is rare in the United States.

G) INCORRECT:

Elevated serum IgA levels are seen in Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP), which can manifest with joint pain and evidence of renal disease in a young patient. However, HSP characteristically occurs after a respiratory tract infection, all patients develop a palpable purpura rash (without thrombocytopenia), most patients develop gastrointestinal complaints (e.g., abdominal pain, vomiting, melena), and the most common manifestation of renal involvement is hematuria (proteinuria is rare). In addition, this patient's chronic fever, fatigue, pancytopenia, lymphadenopathy, and oral ulcers are not typical of HSP.
questions.hint: This patient presents with recurrent arthritis affecting two large joints, painless oral ulcers, pancytopenia, proteinuria, and nonspecific systemic findings (fever, weight loss, lymphadenopathy). Adults with this patient's condition also commonly have a characteristic erythematous facial rash with sparing of the nasolabial folds.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old primigravid woman at 16 weeks' gestation comes to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of vaginal bleeding. Pregnancy has been uncomplicated and she has been receiving standard prenatal care. A viable uterine pregnancy was confirmed on ultrasonography during a prenatal care visit 2 weeks ago. Medical history is remarkable for recurrent episodes of pain in her right wrist and both knees. She smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 11 years but quit when she became pregnant. Pelvic examination shows an open cervical os and blood within the vaginal vault. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
9.6 g/dL


Leukocyte count
8200/mm3



Platelet count
140,000/mm3



Prothrombin time
14 seconds


Partial thromboplastin time
46 seconds


Serum



 Na+

136 mEq/L


 K+

4.1 mEq/L


 Cl-

101 mEq/L


 Urea nitrogen
12 mg/dL


 Creatinine

1.3 mg/dL


 AST
20 U/L


 ALT
15 U/L


Ultrasonography shows an intrauterine pregnancy and no fetal cardiac activity. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's examination findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Placenta previa usually presents in the 3rd trimester with sudden onset of painless, bright red vaginal bleeding that stops spontaneously after 1–2 hours. This patient's presentation (2-day history of vaginal bleeding, absent fetal cardiac activity at 16 weeks' gestation) is inconsistent with placenta previa.

B) INCORRECT:

Preeclampsia is a condition that can be diagnosed after 20 weeks' of gestation; the majority of cases occur after 34 weeks' gestation. While slightly elevated creatinine levels and mild thrombocytopenia in a later stage of pregnancy could indicate preeclampsia, this woman is only at 16 weeks of gestation.

C) INCORRECT:

Velamentous cord insertion increases the risk for rupture of the cord vessels with subsequent fetal hypoxia, especially if the fetal membranes rupture. While this condition presents with abnormal vaginal bleeding in the mother and can cause fetal death, it usually does not present until the 3rd trimester.

D) INCORRECT:

Chromosomal abnormalities are the most common fetal cause for spontaneous abortions, particularly in the 1st and early 2nd trimester. Although a chromosomal abnormality cannot be definitively ruled out, more common chromosomal abnormalities (e.g., Down syndrome, Edwards syndrome) are likely to be detected during the first-trimester screening. This patient's symptoms and laboratory results suggest a different underlying condition.

E) INCORRECT:

Subchorionic hematomas are a common ultrasound finding in women with vaginal bleeding. Since the ultrasound both 2 weeks ago and today showed no signs of this condition, it is an unlikely cause of this patient's symptoms.

F) INCORRECT:

Hyperfibrinolysis is a condition that causes abnormal bleeding. Laboratory tests typically show a normal platelet count and increased prothrombin time and aPTT. While hyperfibrinolysis can cause peripartum complications due to excessive bleeding, this patient's laboratory findings and symptoms suggest a different diagnosis.

G) CORRECT:

This patient's examination findings are most likely caused by APS secondary to SLE. Patients with APS form procoagulant antibodies (anticardiolipin, anti-β2-glycoprotein 1, and lupus anticoagulant antibodies) that can lead to placental thrombosis and consequent miscarriage. To establish the diagnosis of APS, serology for antiphospholipid antibodies should be performed.
questions.hint: This patient presents with vaginal bleeding and absent fetal cardiac activity, both of which are consistent with an inevitable abortion. Her history of recurrent joint pain, anemia, thrombocytopenia, increased PTT, and elevated creatinine suggests systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) with antiphospholipid syndrome (APS).

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of fatigue, dark urine, and a feeling of heaviness in her legs. Two weeks ago, she returned from a vacation to Brazil, where she spent most of her days exploring the city of Rio de Janeiro on foot. She also gained 3 kg (7 lb) during her vacation. She has systemic lupus erythematosus. Her only medication is hydroxychloroquine. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 162/98 mm Hg. Physical examination shows 2+ pretibial edema bilaterally. Urinalysis shows:


Blood
3+


Protein
1+


RBC
6–8/hpf with dysmorphic features


RBC casts
numerous


WBC
8/hpf


WBC casts
rare


Bacteria
negative


Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's leg findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chronic venous insufficiency (CVI) is characterized by lower extremity discomfort, edema, and pain, but it is generally unilateral. Venous insufficiency causes peripheral edema due to increased capillary hydrostatic pressure. In addition, the symptoms of CVI are improved by walking and the condition is not associated with pathological findings on urinalysis. Lastly, in a patient with recent onset of symptoms of CVI, edema would most likely be limited to the ankles.
Image Description:

Yellow-brown skin discoloration (hemosiderin deposition) and edema is present. A varicose vein can be seen on the anterior aspect of the right leg below the knee.

These changes are consistent with CEAP class 4 venous insufficiency.

B) INCORRECT:

In a patient with leg swelling, lymphedema secondary to lymphatic obstruction should be considered as a possible cause. While most cases of lymphedema are unilateral (e.g., due to tumors or inflammation), this patient could have contracted lymphatic filariasis during her travels, which can manifest with bilateral swelling. However, in the absence of further features of filariasis (e.g., fever, painful lymphadenopathy), this diagnosis is unlikely.
Image Description:

Photograph of the legs of an adult male

Severe edema of the lower legs.

This is likely due to an infection with tropical roundworms (lymphatic filariasis).

C) INCORRECT:

Increased peripheral capillary permeability is most commonly caused by inflammation, allergic reactions, or tissue damage (e.g., severe burns). The resulting edema is usually localized and not bilateral. While bilateral edema of the legs can occur in patients with a systemic capillary leak (caused by e.g., sepsis), features of the underlying disease (e.g., fever, tachycardia) and generalized edema would also be expected.

D) INCORRECT:

Renal protein loss leading to a decreased capillary oncotic pressure is a characteristic feature of nephrotic syndrome, a condition caused by damage to the glomerular filtration barrier (e.g., secondary to SLE). While nephrotic syndrome manifests with features similar to those seen in this patient (e.g., edema, weight gain), renal protein loss is more pronounced and hematuria does not occur. Renal protein loss can also occur in patients with nephritic syndrome, which this patient has; however, this patient's 1+ proteinuria does not adequately explain her pretibial edema.

E) CORRECT:

This patient presents with features of nephritic syndrome, a condition caused by inflammatory damage to the glomerular capillary wall (e.g., due to lupus nephritis). Disruption of the glomerular filtration barrier leads to decreased glomerular filtration rate and subsequent retention of salt and water. The resulting volume overload manifests as peripheral edema (due to increased capillary hydrostatic pressure), hypertension, and, in severe cases, jugular venous distension and pulmonary edema. The degree of proteinuria in patients with nephritic syndrome varies; significant loss of protein may contribute to further edema formation but is not the primary cause of edema in these patients.
questions.hint: This patient has a history of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and presents with fatigue, hypertension, bilateral lower extremity edema, and nephritic urinary sediment (hematuria with acanthocytes, mild proteinuria, RBC casts, and sterile pyuria). These features suggest nephritic syndrome secondary to lupus nephritis.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 30-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of a recurring rash on her face, arms, and hands, and episodic pain in both wrists. She also reports chest pain on deep inhalation, muscle aches, and fatigue that caused her to quit dancing classes. Her only medication is occasional ibuprofen for the wrist pain. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows an erythematous rash on the extensor surfaces of the arms and hands, and over the cheeks and nasal bridge, sparing the nasolabial folds. There are three small, nontender ulcers on the hard palate. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Leukocyte count
4000/mm3



Platelet count
90,000/mm3



Erythrocyte sedimentation rate
80 mm/h


Serum



 Antinuclear antibodies

positive


 Creatine kinase
66 U/L


Urine



 Protein

3+


 Blood

1+


 RBCs
5−10/hpf


 WBCs
10–15/hpf


Which of the following diagnostic tests is most appropriate to establish a treatment plan for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Skin biopsy is appropriate to diagnose acute cutaneous lupus erythematosus with an atypical presentation (e.g., without malar or maculopapular rash) and to rule out other cutaneous diseases with similar features (e.g., dermatomyositis). This patient has the typical presentation of SLE; therefore, a skin biopsy is not indicated.

B) CORRECT:

Lupus nephritis (LN) develops in approximately 50% of individuals with SLE and is a major cause of morbidity and mortality. Manifestations of LN vary from an initially asymptomatic state with normal creatinine concentration to nephrotic syndrome or nephritic syndrome. Periodic screening with urinalysis and creatinine measurement is therefore recommended for all individuals with SLE. A kidney biopsy is indicated if the patient has hematuria (as seen here), severe proteinuria, urine cell casts, or an unexplained rise in creatinine. The biopsy is performed to identify the histopathological type of LN and determine the severity of renal involvement, which is a deciding factor in whether a patient with LN requires specific immunosuppressants (e.g., cyclophosphamide, mycophenolate mofetil) in addition to glucocorticoids during the induction therapy phase.

C) INCORRECT:

X-ray of the hands may be performed to rule out diseases that can manifest with fatigue and symmetrical pain in the joints of the hands, such as rheumatoid arthritis. However, this patient's presentation is consistent with SLE, and an x-ray of the hands would most likely be normal because SLE usually causes nonerosive, nondeforming arthritis. In this patient, a different diagnostic test is more appropriate because the outcome affects further management.

D) INCORRECT:

Transthoracic echocardiography is indicated in patients with suspected pericarditis to evaluate for pericardial effusion. Patients with SLE can present with involvement of serosal surfaces, such as the pericardium, pleura, and peritoneum. This patient's pleuritic chest pain (pain on deep inhalation) is unlikely due to pericarditis because other features of pericardial involvement (e.g., pericardial friction rub or faint heart sounds) are absent. Instead, it is most likely caused by pleuritis due to SLE. Pleuritis can be further evaluated using a chest x-ray or a CT scan.

E) INCORRECT:

Electromyography (EMG) is indicated in patients with suspected inflammatory myopathy, such as polymyositis or dermatomyositis, which manifest with muscle aches and elevated inflammatory markers (e.g., ESR). However, muscle enzymes (e.g., creatine kinase) are typically elevated in inflammatory myopathies. This patient most likely has SLE, for which EMG is not required to establish the diagnosis or determine further management.
questions.hint: Malar rash, painless oral ulcers, fatigue, arthralgias, myalgias, thrombocytopenia, leukopenia, increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), and positive antinuclear antibodies (ANAs) raise concern for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

questions.text:
A 34-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of episodic pain in both wrists and a recurring rash. She also reports chest pain on deep inhalation and fatigue that caused her to quit dancing classes. Her only medication is occasional ibuprofen for the wrist pain. She is sexually active with one male partner, and they use condoms consistently. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows an erythematous rash on the extensor surfaces of the arms and hands, and over the cheeks and nasal bridge, sparing the nasolabial folds. There are three small, nontender ulcers on the hard palate. Laboratory studies show:


Leukocyte count
4000/mm3



Platelet count
90,000/mm3



Erythrocyte sedimentation rate
80 mm/h


Serum



 Creatinine

1.4 mg/dL


 Antinuclear antibodies
positive


 VDRL
positive


Urine



 Protein

2+


 Blood

1+


 RBCs
5−10/hpf


 WBCs
10–15/hpf


Serum creatinine concentration was 1.2 mg/dL at a visit 2 years ago. A renal biopsy is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Focal thinning of the glomerular basement membrane
Normal glomeruli with tubular lipid deposits
Glomerular fibrosis with extensive crescent formation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Isolated mesangial IgA-based immune complex deposition is seen on immunohistochemistry in IgA nephropathy, which causes nephritic syndrome. However, IgA nephropathy manifests during or following an upper respiratory tract or gastrointestinal infection, which this patient does not report. Lupus nephritis is not associated with isolated mesangial IgA deposition.

B) INCORRECT:

On electron microscopy, focal thinning of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) alternating with focal GBM thickening is characteristic of Alport syndrome. This condition manifests with nephritic syndrome but would not cause a rash, joint pain, or oral ulcers. Instead, ocular disease (e.g., anterior lenticonus, retinopathy) and sensorineural hearing loss would be expected with Alport syndrome. This patient has lupus nephritis, which is typically associated with a thickened GBM.

C) INCORRECT:

Normal-appearing glomeruli with lipid deposits in the renal tubular epithelium are classically seen on light microscopy in minimal change disease (MCD). This condition manifests with nephrotic syndrome, not nephritic syndrome. This patient has lupus nephritis, which leads to visible changes in the glomeruli.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of tissue obtained from renal biopsy (H&E stain; high magnification)

The basement membrane of the glomerulus is intact, the mesangium does not show proliferation. The capillary lumens are visible and there are no vascular changes.

This is the typical appearance of a glomerulus in minimal change disease.

D) CORRECT:

Lupus nephritis is a common complication of SLE and can manifest with nephritic or nephrotic syndrome. Immunohistochemistry would show glomerular immune complex deposition in patients with lupus nephritis. In this condition, renal damage is mediated by autoantibodies targeted against nuclear antigens (e.g., anti-dsDNA), which form immune complexes that are deposited in the glomerular mesangial, subendothelial, and subepithelial spaces. These depositions lead to intrarenal complement activation, which results in proliferation and thickening of the mesangium, the capillary walls, and/or glomerular basement membrane. The histopathological changes in lupus nephritis resemble those of membranous nephropathy, diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis, and, in severe cases, crescentic glomerulonephritis. The levels of anti-dsDNA antibodies correlate with the severity of lupus nephritis. Treatment of lupus nephritis depends on the severity of the disease and typically involves the administration of high-dose glucocorticoids and cytostatic drugs such as mycophenolate mofetil or cyclophosphamide. Antihypertensive drugs may be necessary in case of chronic kidney failure.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a renal cortex biopsy specimen (PAS stain; 250x magnification)

Sections of numerous tubules and vessels and three centrally located renal glomeruli (blue outlines) are visible. The latter show a partially increased mesangial cell density (examples indicated by black outlines), thickened capillary loops (due to subepithelial immune complex deposits; examples indicated by blue overlay), extracapillary epithelial proliferation (examples indicated by yellow overlay), and diffuse glomerulosclerosis (examples indicated by arrowheads).

These findings are characteristic of diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis, the most common form of lupus nephritis, in which more than half of the glomeruli are affected.

E) INCORRECT:

Glomerular fibrosis with extensive crescent formation on light microscopy indicates rapidly progressive (crescentic) glomerulonephritis (RPGN). RPGN is seen in severe lupus nephritis and manifests with nephritic syndrome but would cause a rapid rise in serum creatinine, which is not seen here. The mild increase in creatinine over a period of one year indicates a less severe course of disease.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a kidney biopsy sample (PAS stain; very high magnification)

The glomerulus shows a hypercellular, crescent-shaped zone (green overlay) with an inflammatory infiltrate (examples of macrophages indicated by arrowheads).

Glomerular crescent formation is a characteristic histological finding in RPGN.
questions.hint: Malar rash, painless oral ulcers, fatigue, arthralgias, pleuritic chest pain, cytopenia (e.g., thrombocytopenia, leukopenia), increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and positive antinuclear antibodies raise concern for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Because SLE can be associated with anticardiolipin antibodies, and the nontreponemal tests (e.g., VDRL) use cardiolipin, patients with SLE may have a false-positive nontreponemal test. Proteinuria with hematuria is consistent with nephritic syndrome.

questions.text: A 26-year-old African American woman comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of a nonproductive cough and chest pain. The pain is sharp and worse when she inhales deeply. During this time, she has also had two episodes of hematuria. Over the past 6 months, she has had intermittent pain, stiffness, and swelling in her fingers and left knee. She has had two miscarriages, at age 22 and 24. Her only medication is minocycline for acne vulgaris. Her temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 138/85 mm Hg. Physical examination shows an erythematous rash on her face. There is mild tenderness over the metacarpophalangeal joints bilaterally with no warmth or erythema. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Low serum levels of C3 and C4
Bilateral enlargement of the hilar lymph nodes

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antihistone antibodies are present in approx. 95% of cases of drug-induced lupus erythematosus (DILE). This patient is currently receiving treatment with minocycline, which can cause DILE. However, minocycline-induced lupus is rare and only < 1% of cases manifest with pleuritis. Additionally, systemic involvement (e.g., lupus nephritis) is even more uncommon in patients with DILE.

B) CORRECT:

SLE is an autoimmune disease characterized by the formation of antibodies and immune complexes that then deposit in different tissues, which causes inflammation and organ dysfunction. These antibodies can activate the complement cascade, leading to low serum levels of C3 and C4. Complement levels are a marker of disease activity and may be used to monitor treatment response.

While antinuclear antibodies are highly sensitive for SLE, anti-dsDNA and anti-Sm antibodies have the highest specificity for this condition. Up to 40% of patients with SLE have antiphospholipid antibodies that predispose for thrombotic events and spontaneous abortions.

C) INCORRECT:

SLE is associated with secondary antiphospholipid syndrome, an autoimmune disease that increases the risk of thrombosis and spontaneous abortions as a result of procoagulant antibodies such as lupus anticoagulant and anticardiolipin. This patient has had two spontaneous abortions, which should raise concern for antiphospholipid syndrome. Patients with antiphospholipid syndrome have a coagulation defect, manifesting with prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) and, in some cases, prolonged prothrombin time (PT). In addition, SLE is associated with thrombocytopenia, which may manifest with prolonged (not shortened) bleeding time.

D) INCORRECT:

Erosions of the metacarpophalangeal joints and/or other joints are commonly seen in patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA), not SLE. Arthritis and/or arthralgia are seen in > 90% of patients with SLE, most commonly affecting the hands or the knees. However, arthritis in SLE is typically nonerosive and nondeforming.

E) INCORRECT:

Bilateral enlargement of the hilar lymph nodes is commonly seen in patients with sarcoidosis, which most frequently affects young African American women. Sarcoidosis can manifest with chest pain, nonproductive cough, fever, arthritis, and skin involvement (lupus pernio). However, it would not manifest with renal involvement (e.g., hematuria). Moreover, bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy is not typically seen in SLE.

Lupus pernio is a variant of cutaneous sarcoidosis that commonly involves the nose and cheeks and causes an indurated rash with erythematous or violaceous nodules and plaques. In contrast, the classic malar rash associated with SLE typically manifests as a flat or minimally raised, erythematous or violaceous rash with mild scaling.

F) INCORRECT:

Renal involvement is present in approx. 50% of patients with SLE and is a crucial prognostic factor, as it is associated with high morbidity and mortality. Lupus nephritis is caused by immune-complex mediated damage to the glomerulus, not by cytotoxic antibodies.
questions.hint: This young woman presents with features of pleuritis (chest pain with deep inspiration), interstitial lung disease (dry cough), nephritis (hematuria), and arthritis (joint pain and stiffness). Along with her facial rash, low-grade fever, and history of multiple spontaneous abortions (indicating antiphospholipid syndrome), these findings should raise concern for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

questions.text: A 57-year-old man comes to the physician because of sudden-onset fever, malaise, and pain and swelling of his wrists and ankles that began a week ago. One month ago, he was started on hydralazine for adjunctive treatment of hypertension. His temperature is 37.8°C (100°F). Examination shows swelling, tenderness, warmth, and erythema of both wrists and ankles; range of motion is limited. Further evaluation is most likely to show an increased level of which of the following autoantibodies?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anti-dsDNA antibodies are highly specific for SLE. These antibodies are rarely found in patients with drug-induced lupus erythematosus.

B) INCORRECT:

Anti-Smith antibodies are highly specific for SLE. These antibodies are rarely found in patients with drug-induced lupus erythematosus.

C) INCORRECT:

Anti-β2-glycoprotein antibodies are associated with antiphospholipid syndrome (APS), which can occur in patients with idiopathic SLE. APS is rare in patients with drug-induced lupus erythematosus.

D) CORRECT:

Anti-histone antibodies are present in most cases of drug-induced lupus erythematosus (DILE). Since anti-histone antibodies are a subtype of antinuclear antibodies (ANA), ANA will also be positive. Other common triggers of DILE include procainamide, sulfa drugs, methyldopa, isoniazid, and phenytoin. DILE can have many of the features of idiopathic SLE such as fever, arthritis, malar rash, and serositis. However, unlike idiopathic SLE, DILE does not affect the oral mucosa, brain, or kidneys and is typically self-limiting after discontinuation of the offending drug.

E) INCORRECT:

Anti-Jo-1 antibodies are associated with polymyositis and dermatomyositis, which manifest with symmetrical proximal muscle weakness. These antibodies are not typically found in patients with drug-induced lupus erythematosus.
questions.hint: The onset of lupus-like symptoms (fever, malaise, polyarthritis) soon after starting hydralazine therapy indicates drug-induced lupus erythematosus. Idiopathic systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) can manifest similarly but it is less common in men (90% of patients with idiopathic SLE are women) and is not associated with hydralazine therapy.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fatigue and joint pain for the past 4 months. Examination shows erythema with scaling on both cheeks that spares the nasolabial folds and two 1-cm ulcers in the oral cavity. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Lymphocytopenia is a typical finding in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus, particularly during active disease, and is presumably caused by autoimmune-mediated cell destruction. Both at diagnosis and throughout the disease, decreased cell counts of all lineages may be present, with anemia being the most common hematological abnormality.

B) INCORRECT:

An increased platelet count would not be expected in patients with SLE. Rather, mild thrombocytopenia occurs in up to 50% of patients due to autoimmune-mediated cell destruction. Thrombocytosis has been noted in patients who have experienced autosplenectomy as part of SLE disease progression, but this is far less common than thrombocytopenia.

C) INCORRECT:

A key element of the pathogenesis of this patient's SLE is the accelerated triggering of apoptosis due to an overactive immune system. The subsequent increased demand for the clearance of cellular debris places an increased burden on the complement system, which helps to mediate the phagocytosis of dead cells. Therefore, patients with SLE exhibit notably decreased complement 3 and 4 levels.

D) INCORRECT:

Increased prothrombin time (PT) can be caused by liver cirrhosis, vitamin K deficiency, warfarin therapy, or disseminated intravascular coagulation. In patients with SLE, increased partial thromboplastin time (PTT) due to the presence of antiphospholipid antibodies would be expected rather than increased PT.

E) INCORRECT:

The autoimmune nature of this patient's SLE would lead to increased gamma globulin production due to an overly active immune system. Decreased gamma globulin levels are seen in immunodeficiencies or can be caused by certain drugs (e.g., sulfasalazine).
questions.hint: Arthralgia, a malar rash, and oral ulcers in a young, female patient make systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 5-day history of fever, joint pain, malaise, and a diffuse rash. Two months ago, he was diagnosed with latent tuberculosis and the appropriate treatment was administered. Examination shows a scaly, maculopapular rash over the chest, arms, and back. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

INH decreases the activity of pyridoxal kinase, which reduces the absorption and the activation of vitamin B6. INH use can therefore be associated with symptoms of vitamin B6 deficiency (e.g., hyperirritability, peripheral neuropathy, sideroblastic anemia, glossitis, and/or cheilitis). However, decreased pyridoxal kinase activity would not account for other INH-associated adverse reactions, like fever or diffuse rash, which are seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Decreased activity of acetaldehyde dehydrogenase reduces the clearance of acetaldehyde, a byproduct of alcohol metabolism. Acetaldehyde causes the symptoms of alcohol intoxication (e.g., headache, flushing, sweating, tachycardia, nausea, and vomiting). Disulfiram, an acetaldehyde dehydrogenase inhibitor, can be used in the treatment of alcohol dependence to increase the discomfort associated with alcohol consumption. A disulfiram-like reaction is also associated with metoclopramide and procarbazine. However, a disulfiram-like reaction would not be observed with the use of INH and would not manifest with fever and diffuse rash, which are present in this patient. Furthermore, this patient has no history of alcohol use disorder.

C) CORRECT:

N-acetyltransferases catalyze the acetylation of arylamine compounds such as isoniazid. Genetic variations (N-acetyltransferase polymorphism) occur frequently and may lead to decreased hepatic acetyltransferase activity. As a result, impaired metabolism of certain drugs can be observed in affected patients ("slow acetylators"). In this patient, it would result in reduced metabolism of INH to the inactive metabolite acetylhydrazine. Increased concentration of isoniazid increases the risk of INH-associated adverse reactions (e.g., DILE, hepatotoxicity, pyridoxine deficiency). Decreased acetyltransferase activity is also associated with other causes of drug-induced lupus: sulfonamides, hydralazine, procainamide, phenytoin, anti-TNF drugs (particularly etanercept and infliximab), and methyldopa.

D) INCORRECT:

Decreased activity of cytochrome P450 is associated with increased toxicity of a variety of drugs (e.g., warfarin, antiepileptics, theophylline, and OCPs) due to decreased drug metabolism. While INH has an inhibitory effect on cytochrome P450 mediated drug metabolism, phase I reactions do not play a major role in the inactivation of isoniazid itself. Decreased cytochrome p450 activity would therefore not be expected to result in the accumulation of isoniazid and increased risk of INH-associated adverse reactions.

E) INCORRECT:

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency (G6PD) is associated with signs of hemolysis, which appear soon after initiating therapy with drugs that cause oxidative stress (e.g., INH, sulfonamides, dapsone, primaquine, aspirin, ibuprofen, and nitrofurantoin). While affected patients may present with fever and malaise, which are seen in this patient, they would not develop a diffuse rash and arthralgia. Moreover, patients with G6PD hemolysis typically have dark urine and jaundice, neither of which is seen here.
Image Description:

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase is the rate-limiting enzyme of the pentose phosphate pathway and oxidizes glucose-6-P to 6-phosphogluconate while reducing NADP to NADPH. NADPH is essential for converting oxidized glutathione back to its reduced form (GSH). The reduced glutathione is capable of neutralizing reactive oxygen species (e.g., hydrogen peroxide) and free radicals, thereby protecting red blood cells from oxidative damage.

In G6PD deficiency, glutathione cannot be reduced and erythrocytes become susceptible to oxidative stress, resulting in damage to the erythrocyte membrane, and thus intravascular and extravascular hemolysis.
questions.hint: This patient was likely treated with isoniazid (INH) for his latent tuberculosis infection. Now he presents with symptoms of drug-induced lupus erythematosus (fever, malaise, rash, and arthralgia), which can be caused by isoniazid. What underlying pathomechanism could have decreased the clearance, and thus increased the half-life, of INH?

questions.text: A previously healthy 13-year-old girl is brought to the physician for evaluation of a 2-month history of fatigue. She reports recurrent episodes of pain in her right wrist and left knee. During this period, she has had a 4-kg (8.8-lb) weight loss. Her mother has rheumatoid arthritis. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F). Examination shows diffuse lymphadenopathy. Oral examination shows several painless oral ulcers. The right wrist and the left knee are swollen and tender. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 9.8 g/dL, a leukocyte count of 2,000/mm3, and a platelet count of 75,000/mm3. Urinalysis shows excessive protein. This patient's condition is associated with which of the following laboratory findings?

choices.text: Leukocytoclastic vasculitis with IgA and C3 immune complex deposition

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A positive monospot test indicates infectious mononucleosis (IM), a common viral infection seen in adolescents/young children. Patients often present with fever, lymphadenopathy (mainly cervical), and fatigue, which lasts for several weeks and can develop pancytopenia and joint pains (due to viral arthritis), as in this patient. However, patients with IM often have a preceding sore throat and do not typically develop oral ulcers or renal damage (proteinuria), making it an unlikely diagnosis here.

B) INCORRECT:

Elevated serum IgA levels are seen in Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP), which could present with joint pain and evidence of renal disease in a young patient (< 20 years). However, HSP characteristically appears after a respiratory tract infection. Patients develop a palpable purpura rash (without thrombocytopenia), gastrointestinal complaints (e.g., abdominal pain, vomiting, melena), and the most common manifestation of renal involvement is hematuria (proteinuria, as seen in this patient, is rare). In addition, this patient's chronic fever, fatigue, pancytopenia, lymphadenopathy, and oral ulcers are not typical of HSP.

C) CORRECT:

Anti-dsDNA antibodies are a subtype of anti-nuclear antibodies (ANA) and are highly specific for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). This patient has many of the clinical criteria for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) acknowledged by the American College of Rheumatology (ACR). Anti-dsDNA antibody correlates with disease activity and constitutes one of the immunological criteria for SLE. Approx. 20% of SLE cases occur in children, where it is more likely to affect Asians, African Americans, and Hispanics. The classic malar rash that is common in adult SLE patients is absent in two-thirds of pediatric cases.

Pancytopenia in patients with SLE is typically the result of immune-mediated destruction of precursor cells within the bone marrow and/or mature peripheral cells.

D) INCORRECT:

Pathergy skin testing is used in the diagnosis of Behcet disease, which can present with oral ulcers (most commonly), arthritis, renal symptoms (hematuria, proteinuria), and fever. However, Behcet disease is uncommon in young children and does not cause lymphadenopathy or pancytopenia, making it an unlikely diagnosis in this case.

The characteristic triad of Behcet disease consists of oral ulcers, genital ulcers, and uveitis, However, the underlying vasculitis can affect multiple systems. Behcet disease is rare in the United States.

E) INCORRECT:

Anti-citrullinated peptide antibodies (anti-CCP) are a group of autoantibodies that are highly specific for rheumatoid arthritis (RA). RA may present with joint pain, constitutional symptoms such as fever, fatigue, and weight loss, and, in some cases, renal involvement (proteinuria) and pancytopenia, as in this patient. Her family history of RA puts her at increased risk of developing the disease. However, this patient's age (RA typically affects middle-aged people), oral ulcers, and lymphadenopathy make RA an unlikely diagnosis.

Anti-citrullinated peptide antibodies are very rarely present in juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) and indicate a poor prognosis. Patients with JIA can also present with fatigue, fever, lymphadenopathy, and joint findings. However, the kidney involvement and oral ulcers seen in this patient are not typical.

F) INCORRECT:

Excessive lymphoblasts on a peripheral smear and/or bone marrow aspirate are suggestive of leukemia. The presence of > 25% lymphoblasts in bone marrow is indicative of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), the most common childhood cancer and an important differential diagnosis in this case. ALL can present with many of the same systemic findings seen in this child (i.e., lymphadenopathy, fever, weight loss, fatigue) and bone pain. However, swollen joints and proteinuria are not typically seen in ALL, making this diagnosis less likely.

G) INCORRECT:

The presence of Reed-Sternberg cells on lymph node biopsy is diagnostic of Hodgkin lymphoma (HL). HL can manifest in children with chronic fatigue, weight loss, fever, and lymphadenopathy. However, renal involvement rarely occurs in HL and involvement of the joints is not typical, making HL an unlikely diagnosis.
Image Description:

Histopathologic image of Hodgkin lymphoma (CD30 immunostain)

Reed-Sternberg cells (middle of the image). CD30 is a surface marker expressed on Reed-Sternberg cells and stains red.

H) INCORRECT:

The HLA-B27 test is positive in up to 85% of patients with reactive arthritis, which can present with asymmetrical polyarthritis and oral ulcers, as seen in this patient. However, this patient lacks other typical features of reactive arthritis such as eye involvement (e.g., conjunctivitis, iritis), and a history of urethritis or enteritis; instead, she presents with renal involvement (i.e., proteinuria) and pancytopenia, which are atypical for reactive arthritis.
questions.hint: This patient presents with recurrent arthritis affecting 2 large joints, possible renal damage, pancytopenia, and oral ulcers, as well as nonspecific systemic findings (fever, weight loss, lymphadenopathy). Adults with this patient's condition also commonly have a characteristic erythematous facial rash with sparing of the nasolabial folds.

questions.text: A 14-day-old male newborn is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a rash on his face for the past 5 days. His mother says that the rash became more prominent after sun exposure. The mother did not receive prenatal care and the newborn was delivered at home. She has had episodes of arthralgia and a rash on her face and neck that often worsened during summer, but she has never been to a physician. The newborn is at the 50th percentile for length and 25th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 79/min, respirations are 45/min, and blood pressure is 82/51 mm Hg. Examination shows erythematous, annular lesions with raised margins in the periorbital area and the scalp. An ECG shows a P-wave rate of 130/min and an R-wave rate of 75/min with no apparent relation between the two. Which of the following laboratory studies for the newborn is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: Polymerase chain reaction for parvovirus DNA
Polymerase chain reaction for rubella virus RNA

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The finding of anti-Ro/SSA antibodies in a newborn is specific for neonatal lupus syndrome, which is a passively acquired autoimmune disease caused by the transfer of maternal anti-Ro/SSA or anti-La/SSB antibodies across the placenta and is the most common cause of complete heart block in a fetus or newborn. As well as manifesting with heart block or a characteristic rash, neonatal lupus syndrome can also affect the hepatic (e.g., hepatosplenomegaly, hepatitis) and hematologic systems (e.g., anemia, neutropenia, thrombocytopenia). The combination of positive antibodies (in mothers or newborns) and either congenital heart block, rash, or hepatic and hematologic findings is required for a diagnosis of neonatal lupus syndrome.
Image Description:

Face of a newborn with erythematous rash

Multiple ring-shaped erythematous patches can be seen around the lips, eyelids, and on the forehead. Neither nose or cheeks are affected by the rash.

These findings are typical of neonatal lupus syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Congenital parvovirus B19 infection is associated with severe aplastic anemia and possibly fetal hydrops, neither of which are seen in this newborn. Furthermore, a congenital atrioventricular block and a periorbital, erythematous, and photosensitive rash would not be explained by this condition.

C) INCORRECT:

Antitreponemal antibodies are used to aid in the diagnosis of congenital syphilis, which can cause a rash in newborns. Furthermore, arthralgias and rashes, as reported in the patient's mother, may be seen in secondary syphilis. However, congenital syphilis is not associated with atrioventricular blocks and photosensitivity. Additionally, the rash in congenital syphilis is maculopapular and typically affects palms and soles rather than the face and neck. Moreover, early-onset congenital syphilis commonly manifests with hepatomegaly, jaundice, and rhinorrhea.

D) INCORRECT:

The presence of anti-dsDNA antibodies is specific for systemic lupus erythematosus, a condition that commonly manifests with a malar rash, arthralgias, and photosensitivity; the mother's arthralgias and rash are consistent with this diagnosis. However, anti-dsDNA antibodies do not cross the placenta; therefore, they would not be seen in a newborn with suspected neonatal lupus syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Congenital rubella commonly manifests with cardiac defects and dermatologic findings. However, this condition is associated with petechiae and purpura (blueberry muffin rash) on the entire body rather than a photosensitive, erythematous, annular rash affecting the face and neck. Furthermore, cardiac defects in congenital rubella infection are typically structural defects (e.g., patent ductus arteriosus) rather than conduction blocks like the atrioventricular block seen here. Moreover, congenital rubella is commonly associated with cataracts and bilateral sensorineural hearing loss.
questions.hint: This newborn's mother reports episodes of arthralgia and a photosensitive rash, both of which indicate systemic lupus erythematosus. The newborn's third-degree atrioventricular block along with a characteristic periorbital rash (erythematous, annular lesions with raised margins) should raise concern for neonatal lupus syndrome.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old homeless woman is brought to the emergency department by the police after having climbed up a tree and refusing to come down. When asked why she climbed the tree, she said she was running away from the dogs and evil faces that were chasing her. She appears disheveled. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination of the skin shows a mild eczematous eruption on the forehead, nose, cheeks, and dorsum of the hands. Examination of the oral cavity shows several small ulcers. Chest auscultation discloses a normal S1 and S2 and a high-pitched grating systolic sound. There are no focal neurological deficits. On mental status examination, she is confused and suspicious with marked psychomotor agitation. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
11.5 g/dL


Leukocyte count
3600/mm3


Platelet count
90,000/mm3


Serum



Na+

138 mEq/L


K+

4.2 mEq/L


Cl-

102 mEq/L


Creatinine
1.1 mg/dL


Glucose
85 mg/dL


Total bilirubin
0.9 mg/dL


ALT
32 U/L


TSH
3.2 μU/mL


HIV antibody
negative


Venereal disease research laboratory (VDRL)
positive


Fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption test (FTA-ABS)
negative


Urine toxicology screening is negative. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows no abnormalities. A 12-lead ECG shows concave, upward-sloping ST-segment elevation in leads I, II, aVF, and V3–V6, and PR-segment elevation with ST-segment depression in aVR. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This middle-aged female patient presents with signs and symptoms indicating abnormalities in various systems: neuropsychiatric (features of psychosis), mucocutaneous (rash on sun-exposed skin, oral ulcers), hematologic (anemia, thrombocytopenia, leukopenia), and cardiac (signs of acute pericarditis: high-pitched grating systolic sound, diffuse ST-segment elevations, PR-segment elevation with ST-segment depression in aVR). This multisystem involvement together with a false-positive VDRL (with negative FTA-ABS) raises suspicion for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). The patient's negative urine toxicology and reassuring electrolytes, glucose, liver, and thyroid function studies further support this diagnosis. In patients with symptoms suggestive of SLE, ANA titer screening is recommended. If the ANA titer is ≥ 1:80, patients can be evaluated according to the ACR classification criteria for SLE to support the diagnostic process. Other neuropsychiatric manifestations of SLE include seizures and delirium. Management of SLE includes induction therapy with a systemic glucocorticoid and maintenance therapy with hydroxychloroquine with or without methotrexate or azathioprine.

Patients taking an equivalent dose of ≥ 40 mg/day of prednisone are at increased risk for glucocorticoid-induced psychosis. Differentiating glucocorticoid-induced psychosis from neuropsychiatric manifestations of SLE can be difficult. Glucocorticoid-induced psychosis tends to occur within 6 weeks of treatment initiation and resolves once glucocorticoids are discontinued.

B) INCORRECT:

Porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT) manifests with skin lesions on sun-exposed skin (e.g., face and neck, dorsum of the hand) in a distribution similar to this patient's presentation. However, patients with PCT typically have fragile skin that blisters with sun exposure or trauma rather than mild eczematous eruptions like those seen in this patient. Healing of these lesions results in scarring and milia formation and can cause areas of hyper- and/or hypopigmentation. Furthermore, PCT commonly manifests with hepatic injury and transaminitis. Finally, pancytopenia, pericarditis, and psychotic features are not typical manifestations of PCT.
Image Description:

A fluid-filled blister is visible on the index finger. Deep ulcers and superficial erosions can be seen on the back of the left hand.

These features are consistent with porphyria cutanea tarda.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral ulcers and skin lesions may raise suspicion for Behcet disease. However, Behcet disease typically manifests with erythema nodosum, papulopustular lesions, or dermatographism rather than eczematous eruptions on sun-exposed skin areas. Moreover, further typical manifestations of Behcet disease include genital ulcers and uveitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Chronic borreliosis (i.e., late Lyme disease) can manifest with neuropsychiatric (e.g., psychosis) and cardiac abnormalities (e.g., pericarditis). However, late Lyme disease typically causes large joint arthritis. Furthermore, oral ulcers, pancytopenia, and a positive VDRL are not expected findings in Lyme disease. Finally, while a rash is characteristic of early Lyme disease (e.g., erythema migrans), it is not a typical feature of late Lyme disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Psychosis in a patient with a positive VDRL may raise suspicion for late (parenchymal) neurosyphilis, a manifestation of tertiary syphilis. This patient, however, lacks the other features of late neurosyphilis, such as Argyll Robertson pupil and tabes dorsalis. Moreover, rash, while characteristic of secondary syphilis, is not a typical feature of tertiary syphilis, which instead manifests with gummas. Furthermore, this patient has a negative FTA-ABS and her symptoms are more consistent with another disease that can cause a false-positive VDRL.

F) INCORRECT:

Whipple disease can manifest with neurologic and cardiac symptoms. However, neurologic findings more commonly seen in Whipple disease include dementia, myoclonus, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia. Although pericarditis (and myocarditis) has been associated with Whipple disease, endocarditis is the most commonly seen cardiac manifestation. Moreover, Whipple disease typically causes intestinal manifestations (e.g., abdominal pain and malabsorption) and is commonly associated with migratory arthralgias of the large joints.
questions.hint: The most appropriate initial treatment for this patient is systemic glucocorticoid therapy.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of fever, fatigue, bilateral wrist swelling, and moderate pain in her left knee. She was diagnosed with systemic lupus erythematosus 7 years ago. She is sexually active with one male partner and uses condoms consistently. Her only medication is hydroxychloroquine. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F) and pulse is 92/min; other vital signs are within normal limits. There is an erythematous macular rash over her face, neck, and both her forearms. The left knee and wrist joints are swollen but cool to the touch and nonerythematous; range of motion in these joints is limited by pain. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 14.5 g/dL, leukocyte count of 9000/mm3, platelet count of 79,000/mm3, and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 30 mm/h. An x-ray of the left knee shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ceftriaxone and azithromycin therapy is the treatment of choice for disseminated gonococcal infection (DGI), which can also manifest with fever and polyarthralgia. However, an erythematous macular rash on sun-exposed areas of skin is not expected; the most common cutaneous manifestations of DGI are vesicular, pustular, or maculopapular lesions (possibly with a necrotic or hemorrhagic center) on the trunk and extremities. Moreover, this patient's consistent condom use makes this diagnosis less likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Adalimumab is indicated in patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) with moderate or severe disease activity after three months of nonbiologic disease-modifying antirheumatic drug therapy (e.g., methotrexate). Although RA also manifests with fever, fatigue, and polyarthralgia, arthralgia in RA more commonly affects the metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints. Moreover, cutaneous manifestations of RA include nontender skin nodules but not an erythematous macular rash. This patient most likely has an acute exacerbation of SLE, for which TNF-α inhibitors are not currently indicated.

C) INCORRECT:

Platelet transfusions are indicated in patients with thrombocytopenia accompanied by significant bleeding, platelet counts < 10,000/mm3 to 20,000/mm3, and/or prior to invasive procedures. Moreover, thrombocytopenia in patients with SLE is most often due to secondary immune thrombocytopenic purpura, in which platelet transfusion is only indicated in cases of severe bleeding (e.g., gastrointestinal, intracranial). Specific treatment is not indicated and the platelet count will most likely increase while the acute exacerbation of SLE is being treated.

D) INCORRECT:

Vancomycin is used as empiric antibiotic therapy for septic arthritis when the synovial fluid's Gram stain discloses gram-positive cocci. Septic arthritis can also manifest with fever, joint pain, and restricted range of motion. However, septic arthritis is usually monoarticular and purulent, with signs of inflammation such as erythema and warmth over the affected joint.

E) CORRECT:

Corticosteroid therapy (e.g., with prednisone) is the treatment of choice for patients presenting with an acute lupus exacerbation. The dose and duration of treatment should be adapted to the severity of the flare. In patients with mild to severe symptoms but no vital-organ involvement (i.e., patients with constitutional, hematologic, cutaneous, or musculoskeletal manifestations) as seen here, a short course of prednisone usually suffices. In severe cases with vital-organ involvement (e.g., patients with renal, pulmonary, or cardiac manifestations), high-dose corticoid therapy and additional immunosuppressants (such as mycophenolate, azathioprine, or cyclophosphamide) may be required.

F) INCORRECT:

Colchicine is indicated as a second-line agent in the acute management of gout and pseudogout for patients who do not tolerate nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (e.g., patients with chronic kidney disease or gastrointestinal ulcers). Although acute gout and pseudogout can also affect the wrists and knees, they typically manifest with monoarthritis rather than polyarthritis. Moreover, affected joints typically show overlying erythema and are warm to the touch. Colchicine can be used in the management of patients with lupus-associated pericarditis. This patient's acute exacerbation of SLE, however, does not manifest with features of pericarditis.
questions.hint: A history of acute onset fever, fatigue, a rash on sun-exposed areas of skin, polyarthralgia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) in a patient with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) suggests an acute lupus exacerbation.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman with coronary artery disease and ischemic cardiomyopathy reports having right-sided chest pain for the past 3 months. Her medications include aspirin, hydralazine, and isosorbide dinitrate.
On examination, she has a temperature of 36.5°C, a heart rate of 80 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute, and a blood pressure of 132/78 mm Hg. Her oxygen saturation is 94% while she is breathing ambient air. Cardiac examination is unremarkable, but pulmonary examination demonstrates diminished breath sounds and dullness to percussion at the right base. The patient has a fine, mildly erythematous rash on her cheeks and nose.
A chest radiograph reveals a right pleural effusion with no significant parenchymal abnormalities. Recent laboratory testing documented the following findings: a positive antinuclear-antibody titer of 1:1280, a positive antihistone antibody, and a negative anti-double-stranded DNA antibody.
Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Discontinue the hydralazine, and continue observation

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Drug-induced lupus is a lupus-like syndrome that is temporally associated with medication use — most commonly hydralazine, isoniazid, procainamide, penicillamine, minocycline, and tumor necrosis factor (TNF) inhibitors. Clinical manifestations may include fever, serositis, arthralgias, arthritis, and rash.

The pathogenesis of drug-induced lupus is unknown, and no standard diagnostic criteria exist: Antinuclear-antibody testing is positive, but a positive anti-double-stranded DNA test is rare (except when associated with TNF inhibitors). Antihistone antibodies are commonly found, but they are also found in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus.

Managing Drug-Induced Lupus

Discontinuing the suspected drug should resolve symptoms within a period of weeks to months.

Key learning point: The most appropriate treatment for drug-induced lupus related to the use of hydralazine is discontinuation of the hydralazine.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with concomitant joint disease can be treated with nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug therapy, but glucocorticoids, such as prednisone, should be reserved for patients with more severe symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Drug-induced lupus is not significantly associated with thromboembolic disease, so a ventilation-perfusion scan is not warranted.

D) INCORRECT:

Treatment with rituximab is not indicated for a drug-induced process that may resolve with drug cessation.

E) INCORRECT:

If the patient has a large effusion, thoracentesis may help relieve symptoms, but placement of a pleural catheter would not be indicated unless the pleural effusion recurred after therapeutic thoracentesis.

questions.text:
A 43-year-old woman who has a history of rheumatoid arthritis with erosive arthritis reports a one-week history of daily fever up to 38.9°C, pleuritic chest discomfort, myalgias, and a new erythematous rash on her face. She states that she does not have increased joint pain or morning stiffness. For the past year, she has taken methotrexate 20 mg orally and etanercept 50 mg subcutaneously, both once weekly, with good effect. Daily folic acid is her only other medication.
Physical examination is notable for a malar rash and decreased breath sounds at both lung bases. Joint examination shows no evidence of active synovitis. Her skin is otherwise clear, and she has no oral ulcerations. An antinuclear antibody assay is positive, at a titer of 1:640, as is a test for anti-double-stranded DNA antibodies. An antihistone antibody test is negative.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A flare of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) would manifest with evidence of active synovitis, including joint pain and swelling, which the patient does not have.

B) INCORRECT:

The risk for lymphoma is elevated in patients with rheumatoid arthritis and may be higher with tumor necrosis factor inhibitors than with other drugs, the acuity of this patient’s presentation and her specific symptoms are more consistent with drug-induced lupus.

C) INCORRECT:

Stevens-Johnson syndrome is a severe drug reaction characterized by extensive skin and mucosal involvement, not merely a malar rash.

D) CORRECT:

Drug-induced lupus is a rare complication of treatment with a tumor necrosis factor (TNF) inhibitor. Lupus induced by TNF inhibitors is associated with a higher incidence of cutaneous manifestations — as well as a higher frequency of positive anti-double-stranded DNA antibodies and a lower frequency of antihistone antibodies — than lupus induced by other drugs. Methotrexate is thought to have a protective effect against TNF-inhibitor-induced lupus; however, cases of drug-induced lupus have been documented among patients receiving concomitant methotrexate and TNF inhibitors.

Development of autoantibodies is relatively common among patients treated with TNF inhibitors but is typically not indicative of disease. Therefore, screening for autoantibodies in otherwise asymptomatic patients using TNF inhibitors is not recommended.

Key learning point: A patient with rheumatoid arthritis who is treated with a tumor necrosis factor (TNF) inhibitor and develops features consistent with lupus likely has TNF-inhibitor-induced lupus.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient’s history of erosive arthritis is more consistent with her diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis than with a new diagnosis of systemic lupus erythematosus. Joint disease in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus is usually nonerosive.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman with a history of obesity, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and systemic lupus erythematosus presents in November and reports that she has been feeling well. Her current medications include prednisone 5 mg daily, lisinopril 20 mg daily, pravastatin 40 mg daily, and calcium and vitamin D supplements.
She received a tetanus-diphtheria booster 2 years ago and is up to date with Covid-19 and respiratory syncytial virus vaccinations, but she has not received any other vaccines for several decades.
Which one of the following vaccination regimens would be safe and appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Pneumococcus, influenza, and recombinant zoster vaccinations

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) are at increased risk for infections. Current vaccine recommendations for these patients include the pneumococcal and influenza vaccines. Because this patient is ≥50 years of age, she should also receive a recombinant zoster vaccine (RZV).

B) CORRECT:

Patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) are at increased risk for infections. Current vaccine recommendations for these patients include the pneumococcal and influenza vaccines. Pneumococcal vaccination should consist of administration of one dose of either 15- or 20-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV15 or PCV20). When PCV15 is used, it should be followed by a dose of 23-valent pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPSV23), usually at least one year later; PPSV23 is not necessary if PCV20 is given.

Because this patient is ≥50 years of age, she should also receive a recombinant zoster vaccine (RZV). Herpes zoster vaccination reduces the incidence of herpes zoster (shingles) and the incidence and severity of postherpetic neuralgia. RZV is recommended for all individuals aged ≥50 years and for those ≥19 years who are or will be immunocompromised. It should be administered in two doses spaced 2 to 6 months apart and is considered safe for patients with a previous episode of herpes zoster or a chronic medical condition. The zoster vaccine live (ZVL), which was contraindicated in severely immunocompromised patients, is no longer available.

Key learning point: A patient over 50 years of age with systemic lupus erythematosus should receive influenza and pneumococcal vaccination as well as the recombinant zoster vaccine.

C) INCORRECT:

Because this patient is ≥50 years of age, she should also receive a recombinant zoster vaccine (RZV).

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) are at increased risk for infections. Current vaccine recommendations for these patients include the pneumococcal and influenza vaccines. Because this patient is ≥50 years of age, she should also receive a recombinant zoster vaccine (RZV).

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) are at increased risk for infections. Current vaccine recommendations for these patients include the pneumococcal and influenza vaccines. Because this patient is ≥50 years of age, she should also receive a recombinant zoster vaccine (RZV).

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman with a history of systemic lupus erythematosus presents 18 weeks’ pregnant with her first child. She reports feeling well and currently weighs 60 kg. Her current medications include prenatal vitamins, prednisone 5 mg once daily, and hydroxychloroquine 300 mg once daily. She has no history of blood clots or renal involvement but does have a history of a malar rash, dry eyes, dry mouth, cytopenias, and arthritis.
Her most recent serology testing reveals positivity for antinuclear antibodies (titer 1:640), anti-Ro antibodies, anti-La antibodies, and anti-double-stranded DNA antibodies but negativity for antiphospholipid antibodies.
Which one of the following management strategies is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Reassure the patient and continue current therapy
Increase hydroxychloroquine to 300 mg twice daily

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoids are considered to be relatively low-risk during pregnancy, especially after the first trimester, at a low dose of <10 mg daily, or when the agent is one that does not cross the placenta efficiently (e.g., prednisone).

B) INCORRECT:

Observational studies suggest that hydroxychloroquine is safe during pregnancy and that discontinuation before or during pregnancy increases the risk for an SLE flare.

C) CORRECT:

A pregnant woman with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) with anti-Ro antibodies has a 1% to 2% risk for delivering a baby with complete heart block, the most serious manifestation of the neonatal lupus syndrome. Although the risk is relatively low, fetal cardiac ultrasound is recommended, and fetal cardiac pacing appears to be an effective intervention if heart block is present.

The best time to evaluate the fetal heart is between 18 and 22 weeks’ gestation. The fetal heart can be difficult to evaluate well in the first trimester, and shadowing from the fetal spine, ribs, and limbs makes cardiac evaluation difficult in the third trimester.

Key learning point: A pregnant woman with systemic lupus erythematosus and positive anti-Ro antibodies should undergo fetal cardiac ultrasound because of the risk for complete heart block.

D) INCORRECT:

Simply reassuring the patient would be inadequate in this setting.

E) INCORRECT:

The maximum daily dose of hydroxychloroquine is weight based, typically 5 to 6.5 mg/kg daily, depending on disease severity, but should not exceed 400 mg daily; thus, 300 mg twice daily would be inappropriate.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old woman with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is hospitalized for acute renal failure. She reports worsening facial rash and fatigue. Her SLE was diagnosed 2 years ago, when she presented with malar rash, arthritis, and oral ulcers; tests for antinuclear antibodies and anti-double-stranded DNA antibodies were positive. At that time, she was started on hydroxychloroquine 200 mg daily, and her symptoms improved.
During her current hospitalization, she is normotensive and has a malar rash, joint tenderness, and swelling of several metacarpophalangeal joints.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
8.8
12.0–16.0


Leukocytes (per mm3)
2300
4500–11,000


Creatinine (mg/dL)
3.8
0.6–1.1


C3 complement (mg/dL)
52
86–184


C4 complement (mg/dL)
3
20–58


Urinalysis reveals >200 red cells per high-power field (reference range, 0–2) with red-cell casts, >100 white cells per high-power field (0–2), negative nitrite and leukocyte esterase, and a spot protein-to-creatinine ratio of 2.5 mg/mg (<0.2). Culture is negative.
Intravenous fluids do not improve the patient’s renal failure. She is started on high-dose glucocorticoid therapy. Renal biopsy reveals class IV lupus nephritis.
Which one of the following immunosuppressive medications is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Initial treatment for nephritis related to systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) consists of glucocorticoids plus either mycophenolate mofetil or cyclophosphamide. When these two immunosuppressive medications were compared directly as induction therapy for lupus nephritis, they had equal efficacy, but mycophenolate mofetil was shown to have a better safety profile. For this reason, mycophenolate mofetil has largely supplanted cyclophosphamide as the preferred first-line agent in treating class III and IV lupus nephritis, especially in patients of childbearing age, to preserve their fertility. In addition, some studies suggest that Black and Hispanic patients may be more likely to achieve a response with mycophenolate mofetil than with cyclophosphamide.

Key learning point: Class IV lupus nephritis should prompt treatment with glucocorticoids and one of these two first-line immunosuppressive medications: mycophenolate mofetil or cyclophosphamide.

B) INCORRECT:

Hydroxychloroquine is an important adjunct therapy in SLE but is not effective for inducing remission in patients with lupus nephritis.

C) INCORRECT:

There is no good evidence to suggest that etanercept or tocilizumab has a useful role as induction therapy for class III or IV lupus nephritis. Etanercept and other tumor necrosis factor inhibitors are often avoided in patients with SLE because of the possibility of exacerbating the underlying disease.

D) INCORRECT:

There is no good evidence to suggest that etanercept or tocilizumab has a useful role as induction therapy for class III or IV lupus nephritis.

E) INCORRECT:

Methotrexate is not an appropriate treatment for lupus nephritis — or for any patient with severe renal insufficiency. Methotrexate use in patients with renal insufficiency can cause life-threatening myelosuppression, and methotrexate toxicity is not reversed by hemodialysis.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old woman with a history of systemic lupus erythematosus reports 3 days of fatigue, rash, and muscle pain. She is not currently taking any medications.
Vital signs are within normal limits, with the exception of a heart rate of 105 beats per minute. She has a faint malar rash and an erythematous maculopapular rash on both lower extremities.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
6500
4500–11,000



Hemoglobin (g/dL)
7.6
12.0–16.0


Hematocrit (%)
22.8
36.0–46.0


Platelet count (per mm3)
217,000
150,000–350,000



Reticulocyte count (% red cells)
5.0
0.5–2.5


A peripheral-blood smear shows 3+ spherocytes but is otherwise unremarkable.
Which one of the following laboratory indicators would confirm the cause of this patient’s anemia?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Total bilirubin levels are elevated in both autoimmune and microangiopathic hemolytic anemias.

B) INCORRECT:

Fibrinogen (an acute-phase reactant) levels are elevated in both autoimmune and microangiopathic hemolytic anemias.

C) CORRECT:

A direct antiglobulin (Coombs) test identifies antibodies bound to the surface of erythrocytes using an agglutination assay. This test is positive in autoimmune hemolytic anemia but negative in other causes of anemia. This patient is probably having a flare of systemic lupus erythematosus, which can lead to anemia from multiple causes, including anemia of inflammation, autoimmune hemolytic anemia, or microangiopathic hemolytic anemia secondary to vasculitis. The patient’s marked anemia is accompanied by spherocytes, which strongly suggest autoimmune hemolytic anemia.

Schistocytes or helmet cells would be consistent with a microangiopathic contribution.

Key learning point: The test that is used to confirm a suspected diagnosis of autoimmune hemolytic anemia is a direct antiglobulin test.

D) INCORRECT:

Lactate dehydrogenase levels are elevated in both autoimmune and microangiopathic hemolytic anemias.

E) INCORRECT:

The haptoglobin level is low in both autoimmune and microangiopathic hemolytic anemias.

questions.text:
A 31-year-old woman who is 26 weeks pregnant is hospitalized with hypertension and a one-day history of acute bilateral lower-extremity edema. She has been treated with hydroxychloroquine 200 mg daily for the past 8 years for systemic lupus erythematosus that has been quiescent. Four months ago, her serum creatinine level was 0.8 mg/dL (reference range, 0.6–1.1), and her urine dipstick showed trace protein.
On examination, she has a blood pressure of 151/90 mm Hg, a heart rate of 88 beats per minute, an appropriately gravid uterus, and diffuse, symmetric pitting edema in both lower extremities.
Laboratory findings are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
10.9
12.0–16.0


Platelet count (per mm3)
151,000
150,000–350,000



Creatinine (mg/dL)
1.6
0.6–1.1


Anti-double-stranded DNA (IU/mL)
>1000
Negative

C4 complement (mg/dL)

Lactate dehydrogenase (U/liter)

Aspartate aminotransferase (U/liter)

Urinalysis shows 2+ protein and 4+ blood. Urine microscopy reveals >100 red cells per high-power field (reference range, 0–2), 4 to 10 white cells per high-power field (0–2), and the presence of red-cell casts.
Which one of the following conditions is the most likely cause of this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The most likely cause of acute kidney injury with features of glomerulonephritis in this patient is lupus nephritis. Nearly half of women with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) have measurable disease activity during pregnancy, and when the disease is active, renal involvement is common. Renal involvement is defined as an active urinary sediment (>5 red cells per high-power field and >5 white cells per high-power field), proteinuria of more than 0.5 grams per day, or both. Patients with SLE and renal involvement are also at increased risk for preeclampsia.

Key learning point: The constellation of acute kidney injury with an active urinary sediment, hypocomplementemia, and elevated anti-double-stranded DNA antibody in a pregnant patient with systemic lupus erythematosus suggests the diagnosis of lupus nephritis.

B) INCORRECT:

Secondary focal segmental glomerulosclerosis can occur in patients with prior renal damage from lupus nephritis. However, proteinuria increases slowly over months to years and does not include an active urinary sediment.

C) INCORRECT:

Preeclampsia is also characterized by proteinuria but does not cause an active urinary sediment and does not depress the serum complement.

D) INCORRECT:

Anti-glomerular basement membrane disease manifests with a rapid decline in renal function and an active urinary sediment, but complement levels should be normal in this disorder. Furthermore, it is extremely rare, and its incidence is not increased with lupus or pregnancy.

E) INCORRECT:

Antiphospholipid syndrome can occur in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus but more commonly manifests with frequent miscarriages and an increased risk for preeclampsia. When antiphospholipid syndrome involves the kidneys, proteinuria usually predominates without evidence of nephritis.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old woman is evaluated for a 6-week history of worsening malaise, nausea, and anorexia. In addition, she recently developed a cough. Within the past few days, her urine has become cola-colored, and her urine output has decreased. She has a history of Raynaud phenomenon, for which she takes amlodipine. Her only other medication is ibuprofen for occasional joint pain.
On examination, she has a temperature of 37.0°C, a heart rate of 87 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and a blood pressure of 158/90 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals bilateral lower-extremity edema with nonpalpable purpura but is otherwise unremarkable.
