Urinalysis shows 3+ blood and 2+ protein. Urine microscopy reveals 40 to 50 red cells per high-power field (reference range, 0–2), many of them dysmorphic; it also shows 4 to 10 white cells per high-power field (0–2) and red-cell casts.
Which one of the following conditions is the most likely cause of this patient’s abnormal kidney function?

choices.text: Interstitial nephritis related to nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug use

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Interstitial nephritis related to nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug use can lead to acute kidney injury. However, in this case, hypocomplementemia and pancytopenia are present.

B) INCORRECT:

Postinfectious glomerulonephritis is typically characterized by hypocomplementemia without a positive antinuclear antibody test. Furthermore, postinfectious glomerulonephritis is a renal-limited disorder and would not explain the pancytopenia.

C) INCORRECT:

Antineutrophil cytoplasmic autoantibody (ANCA)-associated vasculitis may also manifest as nephritis, but the condition is associated with normal complement levels and a negative antinuclear antibody test.

D) INCORRECT:

Atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome results in anemia and thrombocytopenia due to hemolysis. Hypocomplementemia is variable but not universally present and often affects complement C3 more than C4. Atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome should not cause joint symptoms and is typically associated with a negative antinuclear antibody test.

E) CORRECT:

The patient has evidence of glomerulonephritis characterized by an elevated creatinine level, edema, a very active urinary sediment with dysmorphic red cells and red-cell casts, and proteinuria. Given her young age, history of Raynaud phenomenon, rash, pancytopenia, hypocomplementemia, and positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) test, systemic lupus erythematosus with lupus nephritis is the most likely diagnosis. In this case, the cough is most likely secondary to pleural effusions in the setting of fluid overload.

Key learning point: The combination of an elevated serum creatinine level, a positive antinuclear antibody test, hypocomplementemia, proteinuria, and microhematuria in a young woman is suggestive of the diagnosis of lupus nephritis.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old woman presents for evaluation of hair loss. She has a 4-month history of inflamed itchy plaques on the scalp that have resulted in localized alopecia.
During examination, two pigmented, centrally atrophic plaques with overlying alopecia are apparent on the scalp. Similar plaques are observed on the helix and conchal bowl of the left ear (figure).
Which one of the following conditions is the most likely cause of this patient’s hair loss?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Alopecia areata, androgenetic alopecia, trichotillomania, and hyperthyroidism are all causes of hair loss, but these are not associated with dyspigmentation and scarring. Both hyperthyroidism and hypothyroidism can be associated with nonscarring, diffuse hair loss.

B) INCORRECT:

Alopecia areata, androgenetic alopecia, trichotillomania, and hyperthyroidism are all causes of hair loss, but these are not associated with dyspigmentation and scarring. Trichotillomania is a compulsive hair-plucking behavior that results in randomly shaped areas of alopecia with hairs of uneven lengths due to regrowth of previously plucked hairs.

C) CORRECT:

Discoid lupus erythematosus is a scarring inflammatory skin condition that is most commonly seen on photodistributed sites such as the head and neck. Affected sites are characterized by itching or tenderness, with violaceous erythema in early stages that eventuate into dyspigmented (hypo- or hyperpigmented or both), atrophic, scarred plaques. The condition can result in permanent hair loss (scarring alopecia).

Discoid lupus erythematosus may occur in isolation or as a manifestation of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Patients with discoid lupus erythematosus should be evaluated for SLE. Discoid lupus erythematosus is one of the eleven criteria defined by the American College of Rheumatology (ACR) for the classification of SLE. Four of these criteria are cutaneous manifestations of SLE: discoid lupus erythematosus, oral ulcers, malar rash, and photosensitivity. Importantly, these classification criteria are intended to be used for the purpose of defining SLE for clinical trials and were not designed for the diagnosis of SLE in routine patient care.

Key learning point: Scarring alopecia and dyspigmented, atrophic plaques on the scalp and ear suggest a diagnosis of discoid lupus erythematosus.

D) INCORRECT:

Alopecia areata, androgenetic alopecia, trichotillomania, and hyperthyroidism are all causes of hair loss, but these are not associated with dyspigmentation and scarring. In androgenetic alopecia (male- or female-pattern hair loss), there is patterned thinning of the hair (the patterns differ depending on whether the patient is male or female) but no associated inflammation, dyspigmentation, or scars.

E) INCORRECT:

Alopecia areata, androgenetic alopecia, trichotillomania, and hyperthyroidism are all causes of hair loss, but these are not associated with dyspigmentation and scarring. In alopecia areata, the patient has smooth, round, patchy areas of hair loss.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old man is seen for a facial rash that began after a trip to the beach with his family a few weeks ago. He has also noticed pain in his knees and intermittent right-sided chest pain when he takes a deep breath but says that acetaminophen has provided some relief. He has had no fever or chills.
His medical history is notable for Crohn disease that has been well controlled on mesalamine for many years, but he currently has watery diarrhea once daily. He has bipolar disorder and was recently started on chlorpromazine after multiple other medications failed.
On examination, he has symmetric red plaques on his cheeks that extend over the nasal bridge and spare the nasolabial fold. Pulmonary examination is notable for diminished breath sounds at the right base with bronchial breath sounds in the mid-right lung field. Cardiac examination is without abnormality. The rest of the skin and joint examination is unremarkable.
Which one of the following tests is most likely to be positive in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anti-double-stranded DNA and anti-Smith antibodies are associated with systemic lupus and lupus nephritis but usually not drug-induced lupus. The exception is drug-induced lupus due to exposure to TNF inhibitors, allopurinol, or minocycline; lupus caused by these agents is more likely to be associated with elevated titers of anti-double-stranded DNA antibody than antihistone antibody. In addition, the clinical presentation of drug-induced lupus is often more severe with these agents than with others.

B) INCORRECT:

Anti-La antibodies are seen in some patients with Sjögren syndrome but would not be expected to be elevated in this patient, who lacks the characteristic features of this syndrome (dry eye, dry mouth, and parotid-gland enlargement).

C) INCORRECT:

Anti-double-stranded DNA and anti-Smith antibodies are associated with systemic lupus and lupus nephritis but usually not drug-induced lupus. The exception is drug-induced lupus due to exposure to TNF inhibitors, allopurinol, or minocycline; lupus caused by these agents is more likely to be associated with elevated titers of anti-double-stranded DNA antibody than antihistone antibody. In addition, the clinical presentation of drug-induced lupus is often more severe with these agents than with others.

D) INCORRECT:

Tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A antibody is associated with celiac disease, which causes itchy vesicles on extensor surfaces and would be less likely to cause a malar rash.

E) CORRECT:

This patient developed arthralgia, probable serositis, and a photosensitive malar rash that spares the nasolabial fold in the setting of a recent exposure to chlorpromazine. These features raise the possibility of drug-induced lupus. Other drugs commonly associated with drug-induced lupus include procainamide, hydralazine, minocycline, methyldopa, and tumor necrosis factor (TNF) inhibitors.

Drug-induced lupus can be skin limited or systemic, although it rarely affects the kidneys. Antihistone antibodies are present in more than 90% of cases and should be tested in patients with signs of lupus and a history of a suggestive drug exposure. Withdrawal of the offending drug results in resolution of symptoms in most cases, although a short course of systemic glucocorticoids may be indicated for patients with disabling symptoms.

Key learning point: The combination of malar rash, serositis, and arthralgia in a patient who recently started taking chlorpromazine should raise suspicion for drug-induced lupus.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old woman reports a 6-month history of fatigue, intermittent fevers, weight loss, photosensitivity, and pain and swelling in her knees and ankles.
Her blood pressure is 150/100 mm Hg. She is pale and has oral and nasal ulcers, patchy hair loss, evidence of arthritis in her knees and ankles, and pitting edema at the ankles.
A urinalysis reveals hematuria and proteinuria.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is a multiorgan-system autoimmune disease with clinical and serologic heterogeneity. The most recent classification criteria from the European League Against Rheumatism and the American College of Rheumatology require that patients have a positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) test and additional clinical and/or immunologic findings to meet criteria for SLE. Although these criteria are meant for research purposes rather than for diagnosis, they serve as a useful starting point in making the diagnosis of SLE.

In this case, the patient has many of the clinical findings included in the classification scheme (photosensitivity, oral ulcers, joint involvement, hair loss, fever, and proteinuria and hematuria likely indicative of lupus nephritis). She also has systemic constitutional symptoms (fatigue and weight loss) that are not part of the classification criteria but that are frequently seen in patients with SLE. In addition, she has hypertension, which is a frequent finding with lupus nephritis. Given this constellation of clinical findings, she should have her ANA levels tested. If they come back positive, then she would meet criteria for SLE.

Key learning point: The combination of arthritis, photosensitivity, glomerulonephritis, and mucocutaneous ulceration suggests a diagnosis of systemic lupus erythematosus.

B) INCORRECT:

Psoriatic arthritis could explain the inflammatory arthritis and can rarely cause a fever, but it is not compatible with the urinalysis findings, mucocutaneous ulcerations, and hypertension in this case.

C) INCORRECT:

Antiphospholipid syndrome can be secondary to SLE but, in itself, does not explain most of this patient’s symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Infectious mononucleosis can cause significant prolonged constitutional symptoms and occasionally even arthritis, but it would not explain all of this patient’s symptoms, particularly the evidence of glomerulonephritis.

E) INCORRECT:

Adult-onset Still disease could explain the patient’s fever and arthritis, but not the oral and nasal ulcerations, urinalysis findings, hypertension, or photosensitivity. This condition typically causes quotidian fevers (which occur once daily), as well as an evanescent maculopapular salmon-pink rash, lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, and leukocytosis.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old boy reports a 6-month history of fatigue, intermittent fevers, weight loss, photosensitivity, and pain and swelling in his knees and ankles.
His blood pressure is 150/100 mm Hg. He is pale and has oral and nasal ulcers, patchy hair loss, evidence of arthritis in his knees and ankles, and pitting edema at the ankles.
A urinalysis reveals hematuria and proteinuria.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oligoarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis would explain the arthritis in four joints, but it is not compatible with the urinalysis findings or with systemic features such as fever, mucocutaneous ulcerations, and hypertension.

B) INCORRECT:

Infectious mononucleosis can cause significant prolonged constitutional symptoms and occasionally even arthritis, but it would not explain all of this patient’s symptoms, particularly the evidence of glomerulonephritis.

C) INCORRECT:

Antiphospholipid syndrome can be secondary to SLE but, in itself, does not explain most of this patient’s symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis would explain the patient’s fever and arthritis, but not the oral and nasal ulceration, the urinalysis findings and hypertension, or the photosensitivity.

E) CORRECT:

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is a multiorgan-system autoimmune disease with clinical and serologic heterogeneity. The most recent classification criteria from the European League Against Rheumatism and the American College of Rheumatology require that patients have a positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) test and additional clinical and/or immunologic findings to meet criteria for SLE. Although these criteria are meant for research purposes rather than for diagnosis, they serve as a useful starting point in making the diagnosis of SLE. In this case, the patient has many of the clinical findings included in the classification scheme (photosensitivity, oral ulcers, joint involvement, fever, and proteinuria and hematuria likely indicative of lupus nephritis). In addition, he has hypertension, which is a frequent finding with lupus nephritis. Given this constellation of clinical findings, he should have his ANA levels tested. If they come back positive, then he would meet criteria for SLE.

Key learning point: The combination of arthritis, photosensitivity, glomerulonephritis, and mucocutaneous ulceration suggests a diagnosis of systemic lupus erythematosus.

questions.text:
A 13-year-old girl presents with a 2-month history of joint pain in her knees and wrists, an erythematous rash on her face (figure), and chest pain on inspiration with no fever. Her symptoms developed 2 months after an upper respiratory infection.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rheumatic fever is an inflammatory process related to recent infection with group A streptococcus. The diagnosis requires supporting evidence of a recent streptococcal infection, which typically precedes the manifestations of rheumatic fever by 2 to 3 weeks. The classic joint involvement is a migratory arthritis, rather than the simultaneous appearance of knee and wrist arthritis. The classic heart involvement is carditis, mostly of the myocardium and endocardium. The classic skin involvement is erythema marginatum, with lesions located on the trunk and proximal regions of the limbs.

B) CORRECT:

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), rheumatic fever, and systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis are inflammatory multisystem diseases that are diagnosed when a patient fulfills several clinical criteria.

The differential diagnosis of SLE is broad, but the combination of findings in this patient — serositis, arthritis, and malar rash (erythema with induration on both cheeks, sparing the nasolabial fold) — is typical of SLE and warrants further evaluation with antinuclear antibody testing.

Key learning point: The findings of arthritis, pleuritis, and a facial erythematous rash in an afebrile teenager are most consistent with a diagnosis of systemic lupus erythematosus.

C) INCORRECT:

Postinfectious arthritis would not explain the facial rash or chest pain in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis can also manifest with arthritis, pleuritis, and rash, but a history of fever is essential for the diagnosis, and the rash usually affects the extremities.

E) INCORRECT:

Infectious mononucleosis usually manifests with a different constellation of symptoms such as prolonged fever, pharyngitis, lymphadenopathy, fatigue, jaundice, and hepatosplenomegaly, occasionally with a diffuse erythematous rash after the administration of ampicillin.

questions.text:
An 11-year-old girl presents with a one-month history of intermittent fevers, associated fatigue, and a weight loss of 4.5 kg. During the past week, she has developed a rash and has started to complain of finger pain.
Her vital signs are normal except for a slightly elevated blood pressure. She appears ill and has blanching erythematous patches on her cheeks that extend across her nasal bridge and spare the nasolabial folds. A painless shallow ulceration is found on her hard palate. She has notable swelling and decreased range of motion in some of her metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints. Strength and reflexes in the upper and lower extremities are normal.
Which one of the following laboratory abnormalities is this patient most likely to have?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fecal calprotectin is a marker of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Although this patient has some features that would raise concern for IBD (prolonged fever, weight loss, oral ulcers, and arthritis), her constellation of symptoms is much more characteristic of SLE. Specifically, IBD-associated arthropathy typically affects the axial skeleton rather than the small joints of the hands, and a malar rash would not be expected in a patient with IBD.

B) INCORRECT:

Leukopenia is a typical finding of SLE, but leukocytosis is not. Leukocytosis is more commonly associated with infection or malignancy.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with SLE can have myositis, which could cause an elevated creatine kinase level, but this is a much less common manifestation than nephritis. Patients with dermatomyositis, which causes an elevation in creatine kinase more typically, may also present with a malar rash, although a heliotrope rash (characterized by a violaceous hue that extends onto the eyelids) is more typical of dermatomyositis. Furthermore, patients with dermatomyositis have evidence of proximal muscle weakness on history, examination, or both.

D) INCORRECT:

Parvovirus infection causes an erythematous malar rash, but the rash gives the patient a slapped-cheek appearance rather than crossing the nasal bridge as seen in this patient. Parvovirus infection can also cause arthralgias, but the arthralgias in children with parvovirus most commonly affect large joints, such as the knees, rather than the small joints of the hands and wrists. Parvovirus infection is also more common in younger children and is typically associated with prodromal symptoms of fever, coryza, headache, nausea, and diarrhea.

E) CORRECT:

The combination of constitutional symptoms, malar rash, painless oral ulceration, and joint pain should trigger further evaluation for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Although SLE in children is relatively rare, it is more common among Black children and Asian children than white children, and the clinical phenotype in children tends to be more severe than in adults (with greater involvement of major organ systems and more rapid accrual of organ damage), thus necessitating a high degree of suspicion.

The most recent classification criteria from the European Alliance of Associations for Rheumatology and the American College of Rheumatology require that patients have a positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) test and additional clinical and/or immunologic findings to meet criteria for SLE. Although these criteria are meant for research purposes rather than for diagnosis, they serve as a useful starting point in making the diagnosis of SLE. In this case, the patient has several of the clinical findings included in the classification scheme and should have her ANA levels tested. If the test results are positive (≥1:80), then she would meet criteria for SLE.

Approximately 60% to 80% of children with SLE present with renal involvement, and the risk for such involvement is particularly high among Black and Asian adolescents. Clinically significant renal involvement ranges from asymptomatic urinary findings to nephrotic syndrome and renal failure. Most children with lupus nephritis present with proteinuria, persistent microscopic hematuria, or both.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis for a school-aged child with prolonged fever, fatigue, arthritis, malar rash, and proteinuria is systemic lupus erythematosus.

Given her young age, pancytopenia, hypocomplementemia, and positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) test, systemic lupus erythematosus with lupus nephritis is the most likely diagnosis. In this case, the cough is most likely secondary to pleural effusions in the setting of fluid overload.

Key learning point: The combination of an elevated serum creatinine level, a positive antinuclear antibody test, hypocomplementemia, joint symptoms, pancytopenia, proteinuria, and microhematuria in a young woman is suggestive of the diagnosis of lupus nephritis.

D) INCORRECT:

Antineutrophil cytoplasmic autoantibody (ANCA)-associated vasculitis may also manifest as nephritis, but the condition is associated with normal complement levels and a negative ANA test.

E) INCORRECT:

Postinfectious glomerulonephritis is typically characterized by hypocomplementemia without a positive ANA test. Furthermore, postinfectious glomerulonephritis is a renal-limited disorder and would not explain the pancytopenia.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is hospitalized for acute renal failure. She reports worsening facial rash and fatigue. Her SLE was diagnosed 2 years ago, when she presented with malar rash, arthritis, and oral ulcers; tests for antinuclear antibodies and anti-double-stranded DNA antibodies were positive. At that time, she was started on hydroxychloroquine 200 mg daily, and her symptoms improved.
During her current hospitalization, she is normotensive and has a malar rash, joint tenderness, and swelling of several metacarpophalangeal joints.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
8.8
12.0–16.0


Leukocytes (per mm3)
2300
4500–13,000


Creatinine (mg/dL)
3.8
0.5–1.0


C3 complement (mg/dL)
52
86–184


C4 complement (mg/dL)
3
20–58


Urinalysis reveals >200 red cells per high-power field (reference range, 0–2) with red-cell casts, >100 white cells per high-power field (0–2), negative nitrite and leukocyte esterase, and a spot protein-to-creatinine ratio of 2.5 mg/mg (<0.2). Culture is negative.
Intravenous fluids do not improve the patient’s renal failure. She is started on high-dose glucocorticoid therapy. Renal biopsy reveals class IV lupus nephritis.
Which one of the following immunosuppressive medications is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Methotrexate is not an appropriate treatment for lupus nephritis or for any patient with severe renal insufficiency. Methotrexate use in patients with renal insufficiency can cause life-threatening myelosuppression, and methotrexate toxicity is not reversed by hemodialysis.

B) INCORRECT:

There is no good evidence to suggest that tocilizumab has a useful role as induction therapy for class III or IV lupus nephritis.

C) CORRECT:

Initial treatment for nephritis related to systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) consists of glucocorticoids plus either mycophenolate mofetil or cyclophosphamide. When these two immunosuppressive medications were compared directly as induction therapy for lupus nephritis, they had equal efficacy, but mycophenolate mofetil was shown to have a better safety profile. For this reason, mycophenolate mofetil has largely supplanted cyclophosphamide as the preferred first-line agent in treating class III and IV lupus nephritis, especially in patients of childbearing age, to preserve their fertility. In addition, some studies suggest that Black and Latinx patients may be more likely to achieve a response with mycophenolate mofetil than with cyclophosphamide.

Key learning point: Class IV lupus nephritis should prompt treatment with glucocorticoids and one of these two first-line immunosuppressive medications: mycophenolate mofetil or cyclophosphamide.

D) INCORRECT:

There is no good evidence to suggest that etanercept has a useful role as induction therapy for class III or IV lupus nephritis. Etanercept and other tumor necrosis factor inhibitors are often avoided in patients with SLE because of the possibility of exacerbating the underlying disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Hydroxychloroquine is an important adjunct therapy in SLE but is not effective for inducing remission in patients with lupus nephritis.

questions.text: Which one of the following medications constitutes first-line therapy for patients with stable systemic lupus erythematosus and no active manifestations of the disease?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Several medications are used to treat patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Hydroxychloroquine, an antimalarial agent that has been shown to prevent disease flares in patients with SLE, is considered to be first-line SLE therapy. Hydroxychloroquine also has antithrombotic effects, which is particularly relevant for patients SLE who have antiphospholipid syndrome.

Key learning point: Hydroxychloroquine is first-line therapy for patients with stable systemic lupus erythematosus and no active manifestations of the disease

B) INCORRECT:

Given its more-adverse side-effect profile, rituximab is not first-line therapy and is typically reserved for patients with manifestations of active SLE, such as lupus nephritis.

C) INCORRECT:

Given their more-adverse side-effect profiles, glucocorticoids (e.g., methylprednisolone) are not first-line therapy and are typically reserved for patients with manifestations of active SLE, such as lupus nephritis.

D) INCORRECT:

Given its more-adverse side-effect profile, azathioprine is not first-line therapy and is typically reserved for patients with manifestations of active SLE, such as lupus nephritis.

E) INCORRECT:

Given its more-adverse side-effect profile, cyclophosphamide is not first-line therapy and is typically reserved for patients with manifestations of active SLE, such as lupus nephritis.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 0, aborta 3, comes to the office for evaluation of recurrent abortions. Each pregnancy resulted in spontaneous abortion in the second trimester. Menses occur at regular 30-day intervals with moderate flow. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. The patient has a history of chronic migraines, Raynaud phenomenon, and occasional joint pain. She appears tired. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 65/min, and blood pressure is 110/65 mm Hg. Examination shows a purple, reticular rash on both calves. Which of the following is most likely to establish the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cryoglobulinemia can lead to cryoglobulinemic vasculitis, which can manifest with arthralgia, palpable purpura, and Raynaud syndrome. In over 90% of cases, it is associated with hepatitis C. This patient does not show any symptoms of hepatitis C (e.g., malaise, nausea, tender hepatomegaly, jaundice). In addition, neither cryoglobulinemic vasculitis nor hepatitis C causes recurrent abortions.

B) INCORRECT:

A complete blood count can help evaluate for disorders that are associated with recurrent abortions, including thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) and heparin-induced thrombocytopenia. This patient, however, does not present with symptoms of TTP (e.g., fever, neurologic signs, signs of low platelet count, hemolytic anemia) or take heparin.

C) INCORRECT:

The major clinical manifestation of factor V Leiden is venous thromboembolism, although heterozygote patients are often asymptomatic. Though women with factor V Leiden may have a higher risk for recurrent loss of pregnancy. This condition is not associated with Raynaud syndrome, arthralgia, or livedo reticularis.

D) CORRECT:

In antiphospholipid syndrome (APLS), antibodies are directed against phospholipids, including cardiolipin, which is an important component of the inner mitochondrial membrane. Anticardiolipin antibodies are associated with several diseases, including SLE and APLS. As this patient most likely has SLE (joint pain, Raynaud syndrome, livedo reticularis) and has had three consecutive abortions, APLS should be suspected. The diagnosis is confirmed by testing for antiphospholipid antibodies (e.g., anticardiolipin antibodies, anti-β2-glycoprotein antibodies, lupus anticoagulant). Systemic anticoagulation (e.g., LMWH) is the cornerstone of APS treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

A peripheral blood smear to identify sickle cells is a preliminary test to diagnose sickle cell disease (SCD). This condition is associated with obstetric complications including preeclampsia, vaso-occlusive episodes, and anemia, and can uncommonly cause recurrent abortions. However, SCD is not associated with Raynaud syndrome, arthralgia, or livedo reticularis.
questions.hint: The patient's joint pain, Raynaud phenomenon, and livedo reticularis are suggestive of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). One comorbid condition of SLE causes thrombosis and recurrent abortions.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman with a history of systemic lupus erythematosus presents to the emergency department with chest discomfort and dyspnea. Her symptoms began suddenly 3 days ago and have been getting progressively worse. She can no longer climb a flight of stairs comfortably. The chest pain is 8 out of 10 in intensity, left-sided and radiates to her neck. The pain worsens with deep inspiration and when she lies flat on her back. She describes having low-grade fevers, rhinorrhea, and a cough approximately 7 days ago, a faint malar rash one day ago, and increased myalgias. Physical examination is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Bronchial breath sounds at the left lower lobe

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary embolism is an important consideration in an SLE patient with acute pleuritic chest pain and/or dyspnea, but in this case, the absence of tachycardia or hypoxemia and the positional nature of the pain argue against pulmonary embolism and in favor of pericarditis. Consequently, asymmetric calf swelling as a sign of deep venous thrombosis would be unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

The positional chest pain features are not typical of pneumonia, which might be associated with bronchial breath sounds.

C) INCORRECT:

Lower-extremity edema can be seen in patients with constrictive pericarditis, but constrictive pericarditis is rare in SLE, particularly without a history of repeated episodes of pericardial inflammation.

D) INCORRECT:

Pulsus paradoxus would be a sign of cardiac tamponade, which can result from pericarditis, but large effusions causing tamponade physiology are unusual in patients with SLE.

E) CORRECT:

Small pericardial effusions and pericarditis are common in patients with SLE and often coincide with other evidence of active SLE flare. On physical examination, a pericardial friction rub is highly specific for pericarditis, although sensitivity is low.

Key learning point: In patients with systemic lupus erythematosus, the most common cause of symptomatic cardiac disease is pericardial involvement, notably small pericardial effusions and pericarditis.
questions.hint: The combination of dyspnea and sudden-onset positional chest pain in the setting of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is suggestive of pericarditis.

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl presents with a 2-month history of joint pain in her knees and wrists, an erythematous rash on her face, and chest pain on inspiration with no fever. Her symptoms developed 2 months after an upper respiratory infection. A photograph of the patient's rash is shown. Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rheumatic fever is an inflammatory process related to recent infection with group A streptococcus. The diagnosis requires supporting evidence of a recent streptococcal infection, which typically precedes the manifestations of rheumatic fever by 2 to 3 weeks. The classic joint involvement is a migratory arthritis, rather than the simultaneous appearance of knee and wrist arthritis. The classic heart involvement is carditis, mostly of the myocardium and endocardium. The classic skin involvement is erythema marginatum, with lesions located on the trunk and proximal regions of the limbs.

B) CORRECT:

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), rheumatic fever, and systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis are inflammatory multisystem diseases that are diagnosed when a patient fulfills several clinical criteria.

The differential diagnosis of SLE is broad, but the combination of findings in this patient — serositis, arthritis, and malar rash (erythema with induration on both cheeks, sparing the nasolabial fold) — is typical of SLE and warrants further evaluation with antinuclear antibody testing.

Key learning point: The findings of arthritis, pleuritis, and a facial erythematous rash in an afebrile teenager are most consistent with a diagnosis of systemic lupus erythematosus.

C) INCORRECT:

Postinfectious arthritis would not explain the facial rash or chest pain in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis can also manifest with arthritis, pleuritis, and rash, but a history of fever is essential for the diagnosis, and the rash usually affects the extremities.

E) INCORRECT:

Infectious mononucleosis usually manifests with a different constellation of symptoms such as prolonged fever, pharyngitis, lymphadenopathy, fatigue, jaundice, and hepatosplenomegaly, occasionally with a diffuse erythematous rash after the administration of ampicillin.
questions.hint: Avoiding sun exposure is essential in this patient's treatment.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman presents for evaluation of hair loss. She has a 4-month history of inflamed itchy plaques on the scalp that have resulted in localized alopecia. During examination, two pigmented, centrally atrophic plaques with overlying alopecia are apparent on the scalp. A photograph of the patient's lesion is shown. Which one of the following conditions is the most likely cause of this patient’s hair loss?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Alopecia areata, androgenetic alopecia, trichotillomania, and hyperthyroidism are all causes of hair loss, but these are not associated with dyspigmentation and scarring. Both hyperthyroidism and hypothyroidism can be associated with nonscarring, diffuse hair loss.

B) INCORRECT:

Alopecia areata, androgenetic alopecia, trichotillomania, and hyperthyroidism are all causes of hair loss, but these are not associated with dyspigmentation and scarring. Trichotillomania is a compulsive hair-plucking behavior that results in randomly shaped areas of alopecia with hairs of uneven lengths due to regrowth of previously plucked hairs.

C) CORRECT:

Discoid lupus erythematosus is a scarring inflammatory skin condition that is most commonly seen on photodistributed sites such as the head and neck. Affected sites are characterized by itching or tenderness, with violaceous erythema in early stages that eventuate into dyspigmented (hypo- or hyperpigmented or both), atrophic, scarred plaques. The condition can result in permanent hair loss (scarring alopecia).

Discoid lupus erythematosus may occur in isolation or, rarely, as a manifestation of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Patients with discoid lupus erythematosus should be evaluated for SLE. Discoid lupus erythematosus is one of the eleven criteria defined by the American College of Rheumatology (ACR) for the classification of SLE. Four of these criteria are cutaneous manifestations of SLE: discoid lupus erythematosus, oral ulcers, malar rash, and photosensitivity. Importantly, these classification criteria are intended to be used for the purpose of defining SLE for clinical trials and were not designed for the diagnosis of SLE in routine patient care.

Key learning point: Scarring alopecia and dyspigmented, atrophic plaques on the scalp and ear suggest a diagnosis of discoid lupus erythematosus.

D) INCORRECT:

Alopecia areata, androgenetic alopecia, trichotillomania, and hyperthyroidism are all causes of hair loss, but these are not associated with dyspigmentation and scarring. In androgenetic alopecia (male- or female-pattern hair loss), there is patterned thinning of the hair (the patterns differ depending on whether the patient is male or female) but no associated inflammation, dyspigmentation, or scars.

E) INCORRECT:

Alopecia areata, androgenetic alopecia, trichotillomania, and hyperthyroidism are all causes of hair loss, but these are not associated with dyspigmentation and scarring. In alopecia areata, the patient has smooth, round, patchy areas of hair loss.
questions.hint: This patient likely has negative titers of antinuclear antibodies.

questions.text: A 14-year-old Asian girl is brought to the office because of a 6-week history of fatigue, 3-kg (6.6-lb) weight loss, and intermittent low-grade fevers. She also reports recurrent episodes of pain in her left wrist and right knee. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F). Examination shows diffuse lymphadenopathy. Oral examination shows several painless oral ulcers. The left wrist and the right knee are swollen and tender to touch. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 10 g/dL, a leukocyte count of 3000/mm3, and a platelet count of 80,000/mm3. Urinalysis shows excessive protein. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although nonspecific, the monospot test is often used to support the diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis (IM), a common viral infection seen in adolescents and young children. Patients often present with fever, lymphadenopathy (mainly cervical), and fatigue, which lasts for several weeks, and can develop pancytopenia and joint pain (due to viral arthritis). However, patients with IM often have a preceding sore throat and do not typically develop oral ulcers or renal damage (as suggested by proteinuria), making it an unlikely diagnosis.

B) CORRECT:

This patient's constitutional symptoms and features indicating multisystem involvement (i.e., musculoskeletal, mucocutaneous, hematological, and renal manifestations) raise concern for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Anti-dsDNA antibodies are highly specific for this condition and correlate with disease activity (especially with lupus nephritis). Prevalence of SLE is highest among Asian, African American, and Hispanic population groups in the US. Approximately 20% of patients with SLE have a disease onset in childhood. The classic malar rash that is common in adult SLE patients is not seen in two-thirds of pediatric patients.

Pancytopenia in SLE is typically the result of immune-mediated destruction of mature peripheral cells and/or destruction of precursor cells within the bone marrow.

Key learning point: Anti-dsDNA antibodies are highly specific for systemic lupus erythematosus and are associated with disease activity, especially lupus nephritis.

C) INCORRECT:

Excessive lymphoblasts on a peripheral smear and/or bone marrow aspirate suggests leukemia. The presence of > 20% lymphoblasts in bone marrow is indicative of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), the most common childhood cancer and an important differential diagnosis in this case. ALL can manifest with many of the same systemic findings seen in this child (i.e., lymphadenopathy, fever, weight loss, fatigue) and bone pain. However, swollen joints and proteinuria are not typically seen in ALL, making this diagnosis less likely.

D) INCORRECT:

The presence of Reed-Sternberg cells on lymph node biopsy is diagnostic of Hodgkin lymphoma (HL). HL can manifest in children with chronic fatigue, weight loss, fever, and lymphadenopathy. However, renal involvement rarely occurs in HL and involvement of the joints is not typical, making HL an unlikely diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Elevated serum IgA levels are seen in Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP), which can manifest with joint pain and evidence of renal disease in a young patient. However, HSP characteristically occurs after a respiratory tract infection, all patients develop a palpable purpura rash (without thrombocytopenia), most patients develop gastrointestinal complaints (e.g., abdominal pain, vomiting, melena), and the most common manifestation of renal involvement is hematuria (proteinuria is rare). In addition, this patient's chronic fever, fatigue, pancytopenia, lymphadenopathy, and oral ulcers are not typical of HSP.
questions.hint: This patient presents with recurrent arthritis affecting two large joints, painless oral ulcers, pancytopenia, proteinuria, and nonspecific systemic findings (fever, weight loss, lymphadenopathy). Adults with this patient's condition also commonly have a characteristic erythematous facial rash with sparing of the nasolabial folds.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman with systemic lupus erythematosus comes to the office because of a 2-day history of fever, fatigue, bilateral wrist swelling, and moderate pain in her left knee. She is sexually active with one male partner and uses condoms consistently. Her only medication is hydroxychloroquine. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F). There is an erythematous macular rash over her face, neck, and both her forearms. The left knee and wrist joints are swollen but cool to the touch. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 14.5 g/dL, leukocyte count of 9000/mm3, platelet count of 79,000/mm3, and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 30 mm/h. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ceftriaxone and azithromycin therapy is the treatment of choice for disseminated gonococcal infection (DGI), which can also manifest with fever and polyarthralgia. However, an erythematous macular rash on sun-exposed areas of skin is not expected; the most common cutaneous manifestations of DGI are vesicular, pustular, or maculopapular lesions (possibly with a necrotic or hemorrhagic center) on the trunk and extremities. Moreover, this patient's consistent condom use makes this diagnosis less likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Adalimumab is indicated in patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) with moderate or severe disease activity after three months of nonbiologic disease-modifying antirheumatic drug therapy (e.g., methotrexate). Although RA also manifests with fever, fatigue, and polyarthralgia, arthralgia in RA more commonly affects the metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints. Moreover, cutaneous manifestations of RA include nontender skin nodules but not an erythematous macular rash. This patient most likely has an acute exacerbation of SLE, for which TNF-α inhibitors are not currently indicated.

C) INCORRECT:

Platelet transfusions are indicated in patients with thrombocytopenia accompanied by significant bleeding, platelet counts < 10,000/mm3 to 20,000/mm3, and/or prior to invasive procedures. Moreover, thrombocytopenia in patients with SLE is most often due to secondary immune thrombocytopenic purpura, in which platelet transfusion is only indicated in cases of severe bleeding (e.g., gastrointestinal, intracranial). Specific treatment is not indicated and the platelet count will most likely increase while the acute exacerbation of SLE is being treated.

D) CORRECT:

Corticosteroid therapy (e.g., with prednisone) is the treatment of choice for patients presenting with an acute lupus exacerbation. The dose and duration of treatment should be adapted to the severity of the flare. In patients with mild to severe symptoms but no vital-organ involvement (i.e., patients with constitutional, hematologic, cutaneous, or musculoskeletal manifestations) as seen here, a short course of prednisone usually suffices. In severe cases with vital-organ involvement (e.g., patients with renal, pulmonary, or cardiac manifestations), high-dose corticoid therapy and additional immunosuppressants (such as mycophenolate, azathioprine, or cyclophosphamide) may be required.

Key learning point: Acute lupus exacerbations without vital organ involvement are best managed with a short course of corticosteroids such as prednisone.

E) INCORRECT:

Colchicine is indicated as a second-line agent in the acute management of gout and pseudogout for patients who do not tolerate nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (e.g., patients with chronic kidney disease or gastrointestinal ulcers). Although acute gout and pseudogout can also affect the wrists and knees, they typically manifest with monoarthritis rather than polyarthritis. Moreover, affected joints typically show overlying erythema and are warm to the touch. Colchicine can be used in the management of patients with lupus-associated pericarditis. This patient's acute exacerbation of SLE, however, does not manifest with features of pericarditis.
questions.hint: A history of acute onset fever, fatigue, a rash on sun-exposed areas of skin, polyarthralgia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) in a patient with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) suggests an acute lupus exacerbation.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man comes to the office because of sudden-onset fever, malaise, and pain and swelling of his wrists and ankles that began a week ago. One month ago, he was started on hydralazine for adjunctive treatment of hypertension. His temperature is 37.8°C (100°F). Examination shows swelling, tenderness, warmth, and erythema of both wrists and ankles; range of motion is limited. Further evaluation is most likely to show an increased level of which of the following autoantibodies?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anti-dsDNA antibodies are highly specific for SLE. These antibodies are rarely found in patients with drug-induced lupus erythematosus.

B) INCORRECT:

Anti-Smith antibodies are highly specific for SLE. These antibodies are rarely found in patients with drug-induced lupus erythematosus.

C) INCORRECT:

Anti-β2-glycoprotein antibodies are associated with antiphospholipid syndrome (APS), which can occur in patients with idiopathic SLE. APS is rare in patients with drug-induced lupus erythematosus.

D) CORRECT:

Anti-histone antibodies are present in most cases of drug-induced lupus erythematosus (DILE). Since anti-histone antibodies are a subtype of antinuclear antibodies (ANA), ANA will also be positive. Other common triggers of DILE include procainamide, sulfa drugs, methyldopa, isoniazid, and phenytoin. DILE can have many of the features of idiopathic SLE such as fever, arthritis, malar rash, and serositis. However, unlike idiopathic SLE, DILE does not affect the oral mucosa, brain, or kidneys and is typically self-limiting after discontinuation of the offending drug.

E) INCORRECT:

Anti-Jo-1 antibodies are associated with polymyositis and dermatomyositis, which manifest with symmetrical proximal muscle weakness. These antibodies are not typically found in patients with drug-induced lupus erythematosus.
questions.hint: The onset of lupus-like symptoms (fever, malaise, polyarthritis) soon after starting hydralazine therapy indicates drug-induced lupus erythematosus. Idiopathic systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) can manifest similarly but it is less common in men (90% of patients with idiopathic SLE are women) and is not associated with hydralazine therapy.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 30-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 6-month history of a recurring rash on her face, arms, and hands, and episodic pain in both wrists. She also reports chest pain on deep inhalation, muscle aches, and fatigue. Physical examination shows an erythematous rash on the extensor surfaces of the arms and hands, and over the cheeks and nasal bridge, sparing the nasolabial folds. There are three small, nontender ulcers on the hard palate. Laboratory findings include the following levels:


Leukocyte count
4000/mm3



Platelet count
90,000/mm3



Erythrocyte sedimentation rate
80 mm/h


Serum



 Antinuclear antibodies

positive


Urinalysis discloses hematuria and proteinuria. Which of the following diagnostic tests is most appropriate to establish a treatment plan for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Skin biopsy is appropriate to diagnose acute cutaneous lupus erythematosus with an atypical presentation (e.g., without malar or maculopapular rash) and to rule out other cutaneous diseases with similar features (e.g., dermatomyositis). This patient has the typical presentation of SLE; therefore, a skin biopsy is not indicated.

B) CORRECT:

Lupus nephritis (LN) develops in approximately 50% of individuals with SLE and is a major cause of morbidity and mortality. Manifestations of LN vary from an initially asymptomatic state with normal creatinine concentration to nephrotic syndrome or nephritic syndrome. Periodic screening with urinalysis and creatinine measurement is therefore recommended for all individuals with SLE. A kidney biopsy is indicated if the patient has hematuria (as seen here), severe proteinuria, urine cell casts, or an unexplained rise in creatinine. The biopsy is performed to identify the histopathological type of LN and determine the severity of renal involvement, which is a deciding factor in whether a patient with LN requires specific immunosuppressants (e.g., cyclophosphamide, mycophenolate mofetil) in addition to glucocorticoids during the induction therapy phase.

C) INCORRECT:

X-ray of the hands may be performed to rule out diseases that can manifest with fatigue and symmetrical pain in the joints of the hands, such as rheumatoid arthritis. However, this patient's presentation is consistent with SLE, and an x-ray of the hands would most likely be normal because SLE usually causes nonerosive, nondeforming arthritis. In this patient, a different diagnostic test is more appropriate because the outcome affects further management.

D) INCORRECT:

Transthoracic echocardiography is indicated in patients with suspected pericarditis to evaluate for pericardial effusion. Patients with SLE can present with involvement of serosal surfaces, such as the pericardium, pleura, and peritoneum. This patient's pleuritic chest pain (pain on deep inhalation) is unlikely due to pericarditis because other features of pericardial involvement (e.g., pericardial friction rub or faint heart sounds) are absent. Instead, it is most likely caused by pleuritis due to SLE. Pleuritis can be further evaluated using a chest x-ray or a CT scan.

E) INCORRECT:

Electromyography (EMG) is indicated in patients with suspected inflammatory myopathy, such as polymyositis or dermatomyositis, which manifest with muscle aches and elevated inflammatory markers (e.g., ESR). However, muscle enzymes (e.g., creatine kinase) are typically elevated in inflammatory myopathies. This patient most likely has SLE, for which EMG is not required to establish the diagnosis or determine further management.
questions.hint: Malar rash, painless oral ulcers, fatigue, arthralgias, myalgias, thrombocytopenia, leukopenia, increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), and positive antinuclear antibodies (ANAs) raise concern for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

questions.text:
A 25-year-old woman is evaluated for a 6-week history of worsening malaise, nausea, and anorexia. Within the past few days, her urine has become cola-colored, and her urine output has decreased. She has a history of Raynaud phenomenon. Her only other medication is ibuprofen for occasional joint pain. Her blood pressure is 158/90 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals bilateral lower-extremity edema with nonpalpable purpura but is otherwise unremarkable. Laboratory findings include the following levels:


Leukocyte count
2800/mm3



Hemoglobin
10.0 g/dL


Platelet count
70,000/mm3



Creatinine
5.9 mg/dL


Antinuclear antibody
positive


Complement C3 and C4 levels are decreased. Urine studies show 3+ blood, 2+ protein, and red-cell casts. Which of the following conditions is the most likely cause of this patient’s abnormal kidney function?

choices.text: Interstitial nephritis related to nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug use

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Interstitial nephritis related to nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug use can lead to acute kidney injury. However, in this case, hypocomplementemia and pancytopenia are present.

B) INCORRECT:

Postinfectious glomerulonephritis is typically characterized by hypocomplementemia without a positive ANA test. However, postinfectious glomerulonephritis is a renal-limited disorder and would not explain the pancytopenia.

C) INCORRECT:

Antineutrophil cytoplasmic autoantibody (ANCA)-associated vasculitis may also manifest as nephritis, but the condition is associated with normal complement levels and a negative ANA test.

D) INCORRECT:

Atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome results in anemia and thrombocytopenia due to hemolysis. Hypocomplementemia is variable but not universally present and often affects complement C3 more than C4. Atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome should not cause joint symptoms and is typically associated with a negative ANA test.

E) CORRECT:

The patient has evidence of glomerulonephritis characterized by an elevated creatinine level, edema, a very active urinary sediment with dysmorphic red cells and red-cell casts, and proteinuria. Given her young age, history of Raynaud phenomenon, rash, pancytopenia, hypocomplementemia, and positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) test, systemic lupus erythematosus with lupus nephritis is the most likely diagnosis.

Key learning point: The combination of an elevated serum creatinine level, a positive antinuclear antibody test, hypocomplementemia, proteinuria, and microhematuria in a young woman is suggestive of the diagnosis of lupus nephritis.
questions.hint: The most appropriate initial treatment for this patient is systemic glucocorticoid therapy in combination with immunosuppressants.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old woman presents with a 3-week history of fatigue, low-grade fevers, and pain in her hands and wrists that worsens upon waking and improves throughout the day. She also notes a red rash on her cheeks that becomes more pronounced after sun exposure. Examination shows mild swelling in her proximal interphalangeal joints and faint ulcers on her buccal mucosa. She experiences morning stiffness lasting about 45 minutes (see lab results).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Hemoglobin
105 g/L
120 - 160 g/L


WBC
3.0 x 10⁹/L
4.5 - 10.5 x 10⁹/L


Urine




 Protein
Present
Absent



Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is a multisystem autoimmune disease predominantly affecting women of childbearing age. It manifests with a photosensitive malar rash, symmetric joint pain with morning stiffness, and oral mucosal ulcers. Hematologic abnormalities such as anemia and leukopenia, along with renal involvement like proteinuria, are common due to immune complex deposition and inflammation. The pathophysiology involves autoantibodies against nuclear components, such as anti-dsDNA and anti-Smith, leading to widespread organ involvement. The combination of dermatologic, musculoskeletal, hematologic, and renal findings supports the diagnosis of SLE.

Key learning point: Systemic lupus erythematosus can present with fatigue, facial rashes, oral ulcers, and joint pain, and is a common autoimmune condition in young women.

B) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid arthritis typically presents with joint pain, morning stiffness, and joint swelling. However, it lacks the photosensitive rash and oral ulcers seen here. Additionally, leukopenia and proteinuria are not typical in early rheumatoid arthritis, which primarily affects joints.

C) INCORRECT:

Dermatomyositis is characterized by proximal muscle weakness and elevated muscle enzymes, not joint pain and stiffness. Its skin findings, such as heliotrope rash and Gottron papules, differ from the malar rash and oral ulcers observed here. Systemic manifestations like anemia and proteinuria are also atypical.

D) INCORRECT:

Sjögren syndrome primarily presents with sicca symptoms, such as dry eyes and mouth, due to exocrine gland involvement. The photosensitive rash, systemic laboratory abnormalities, and oral ulcers seen here are not characteristic of Sjögren syndrome, which lacks significant systemic involvement.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old woman presents with a two-month history of painful joints in her hands and wrists, a new rash over her cheeks that worsens with sun exposure, and growing fatigue. She reports dark urine for the past week. Examination reveals a pinkish rash over her malar region and mild pedal edema. Laboratory testing shows hematuria with RBC casts and mild anemia, but no signs of active infection.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dermatomyositis is known for cutaneous manifestations and inflammatory myopathy. Its characteristic rash includes a heliotrope rash and Gottron papules, not a malar rash. Muscle weakness is a hallmark, but there is no mention of muscle weakness or elevated muscle enzymes. Renal involvement, such as hematuria with RBC casts, is not typical of dermatomyositis.

B) INCORRECT:

Psoriatic arthritis is associated with psoriasis, which presents as erythematous plaques with silvery scales. The malar rash, especially one that worsens with sun exposure, is not characteristic of psoriasis. Renal involvement, such as hematuria with red blood cell casts, is not a feature of psoriatic arthritis.

C) CORRECT:

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is an autoimmune disorder characterized by multisystem inflammation. It frequently manifests with joint pain, a photosensitive malar rash, and renal involvement. Hematuria with red blood cell casts indicates glomerular inflammation from immune complex deposition, a hallmark of lupus nephritis. In SLE, these immune complexes form due to dysregulated production of autoantibodies targeting nuclear antigens, leading to complement-mediated tissue damage. The demographic profile of a young woman aligns with the epidemiology of SLE. Laboratory findings such as mild anemia support the systemic inflammatory state. Additional serological markers, such as antinuclear and anti-double stranded DNA antibodies, would corroborate the diagnosis.

Key learning point: Photosensitivity, malar rash, joint pains, and hematuria in a young patient are indicative of systemic lupus erythematosus with renal involvement, known as lupus nephritis.

D) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is characterized by chronic, symmetric inflammatory arthritis, primarily affecting the small joints of the hands and wrists. However, RA is not typically associated with a photosensitive malar rash or renal findings such as hematuria and red blood cell casts. These features suggest an underlying immune complex-mediated process, which is not characteristic of RA.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old unmarried woman presents with three weeks of facial swelling and bilateral leg edema. She has a 3-year history of systemic lupus erythematosus and reports dark, frothy urine. On examination, she has mild hypertension. Laboratory testing shows a serum creatinine of 146 μmol/L, elevated from her baseline of 72 μmol/L. Urinalysis reveals red blood cell casts. Anti-dsDNA levels are elevated, and complement levels are low. A kidney biopsy demonstrates diffuse proliferative (Class IV) lupus nephritis. She hopes to conceive within the next year.
Which of the following treatment options is most appropriate to induce remission of her nephritis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Diffuse proliferative lupus nephritis (Class IV) is a severe renal manifestation of systemic lupus erythematosus characterized by immune complex deposition and intense inflammation. High-dose corticosteroids rapidly reduce inflammation, while mycophenolate mofetil inhibits lymphocyte proliferation by disrupting guanosine nucleotide synthesis. This combination is effective in achieving remission and preventing renal deterioration. Mycophenolate mofetil is teratogenic, so patients must use reliable contraception during treatment and observe a washout period before conception.

Key learning point: In active lupus nephritis, the combination of corticosteroids and mycophenolate mofetil is an effective high-dose treatment option.

B) INCORRECT:

Belimumab targets B-cell activating factor (BAFF) and is used for non-renal manifestations of systemic lupus erythematosus. It is not effective for the acute phase of diffuse proliferative lupus nephritis, which requires rapid immunosuppression. Clinical trials for belimumab have excluded patients with severe renal involvement, and its safety profile in pregnancy is not well-characterized.

C) INCORRECT:

Low-dose oral prednisone does not provide sufficient immunosuppression for diffuse proliferative lupus nephritis. The severity of this condition necessitates high-dose corticosteroids and additional immunosuppressive agents to control the extensive glomerular inflammation and prevent irreversible renal damage.

D) INCORRECT:

Hydroxychloroquine is beneficial for long-term management of systemic lupus erythematosus but lacks the potent immunosuppressive properties needed for severe lupus nephritis. The aggressive glomerular inflammation in Class IV disease requires a robust immunosuppressant in addition to corticosteroids to achieve remission.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old woman presents with sudden onset confusion, severe headaches, and several episodes of generalized tonic-clonic seizures over the past week. She has a 2-year history of systemic lupus erythematosus and is on low-dose oral prednisone and hydroxychloroquine. Neurological examination shows mild left-sided weakness and decreased orientation to time and place. Urinalysis shows proteinuria (2+). Laboratory testing shows elevated anti-double-stranded DNA and low complement levels (see report).

Blood pressure
150/95 mmHg

MRI of the brain: Multiple scattered hyperintense lesions in the white matter
Which medication is most appropriate to add to her treatment regimen to address her severe CNS involvement?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Severe central nervous system (CNS) involvement in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) requires aggressive immunosuppression due to autoantibody-mediated inflammation and immune complex deposition. Intravenous cyclophosphamide is a potent cytotoxic agent that inhibits B and T lymphocytes, reducing pathogenic autoantibodies and inflammatory activity. It is effective in neuropsychiatric lupus, particularly with confusion, seizures, and MRI findings of hyperintense white matter lesions. Cyclophosphamide penetrates the blood-brain barrier, mitigating immune-mediated CNS damage. Combined with high-dose corticosteroids, it rapidly controls inflammation and preserves neurologic function in severe lupus manifestations.

Key learning point: In cases of severe CNS involvement in systemic lupus erythematosus, cyclophosphamide is used in addition to corticosteroids to control disease activity.

B) INCORRECT:

High-dose intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) modulates the immune response and neutralizes autoantibodies. It is used in autoimmune conditions but lacks the aggressive immunosuppression needed for severe CNS involvement in SLE. IVIG does not effectively address the intense inflammation seen in neuropsychiatric lupus.

C) INCORRECT:

Mycophenolate mofetil inhibits inosine monophosphate dehydrogenase, affecting lymphocyte proliferation. It is used for lupus nephritis and maintenance therapy in moderate SLE. However, its slower onset and primary renal focus make it unsuitable for acute severe CNS flares requiring rapid immunosuppression.

D) INCORRECT:

Plasmapheresis removes circulating autoantibodies and immune complexes, providing temporary relief in some immunologic disorders. However, it is not well-established for acute CNS involvement in SLE, where high-potency immunosuppressants more directly target the inflammatory cascade.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman presents with increased joint pains and fatigue over the past three months. She has a 5-year history of systemic lupus erythematosus and has been maintained on low-dose prednisone and hydroxychloroquine with intermittent flares responding to brief increases in oral steroid doses. She smokes one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 10 years. Laboratory studies show stable renal function with no active urinary sediment and normal complement levels. She reports missing recent follow-up visits.

Blood pressure
120/75 mm Hg

She seeks advice on reducing the frequency and severity of her flares. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Smoking exacerbates autoimmune processes and may reduce the efficacy of medications like hydroxychloroquine in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Tobacco smoke increases oxidative stress and pro-inflammatory cytokine production, triggering lupus flares. Smoking cessation can modulate these inflammatory pathways, reducing flare frequency and severity. Additionally, smoking increases cardiovascular disease risk, already elevated in SLE. A structured smoking cessation program offers a non-pharmacological strategy to improve disease control and reduce the need for additional immunosuppressive interventions.

Key learning point: Smoking cessation is a crucial non-pharmacological intervention in managing systemic lupus erythematosus as smoking can exacerbate disease activity and reduce treatment efficacy.

B) INCORRECT:

Increasing prednisone is used for acute, severe SLE exacerbations. This patient has stable renal function and normal complement levels, indicating no significant systemic inflammation or organ involvement. Her current low-dose prednisone and hydroxychloroquine regimen has been effective, aside from intermittent flares. Prophylactically increasing prednisone exposes her to unnecessary risks without clear benefit.

C) INCORRECT:

Intravenous cyclophosphamide is reserved for severe SLE with major organ involvement, such as lupus nephritis. This patient has joint pain and fatigue, with stable renal function and normal complement levels, indicating no significant organ involvement. Cyclophosphamide would expose her to unnecessary toxicity without evidence of severe or refractory disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Testing for lupus anticoagulant is indicated when there is suspicion of thrombotic events or obstetric morbidity. This patient presents with joint pains and fatigue, without thrombosis or pregnancy-related complications, and has stable renal function and normal complement levels. These findings do not suggest a hypercoagulable state or the need for lupus anticoagulant testing.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman presents to the clinic with persistent joint pain and intermittent morning stiffness in her wrists and hands for the past 4 months. She has a 3-year history of systemic lupus erythematosus and has been taking hydroxychloroquine for the last two years without missing doses. She is reluctant to increase her current low-dose corticosteroid due to weight gain. Examination shows mild swelling in both wrists, no deformities, and no skin lesions. Laboratory studies show normal complete blood count, normal renal function, normal transaminases, and stable complement levels.
Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacologic intervention for better control of her joint symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Methotrexate is a disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD) effective in managing inflammatory arthritis in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) when hydroxychloroquine and low-dose corticosteroids are insufficient. It inhibits enzymes in folate metabolism, reducing T cell proliferation and inflammation. Methotrexate increases extracellular adenosine, exerting anti-inflammatory effects and providing a steroid-sparing benefit, minimizing corticosteroid-related adverse effects like weight gain. It is suitable for non-deforming arthritis in SLE, offering improved symptomatic control.

Key learning point: Methotrexate is a commonly used DMARD for controlling arthritis in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus when hydroxychloroquine alone is insufficient.

B) INCORRECT:

Cyclophosphamide is reserved for severe, organ-threatening SLE manifestations, such as lupus nephritis. The patient has isolated joint symptoms without major organ involvement. Cyclophosphamide's adverse effects, including infertility and severe immunosuppression, make it inappropriate for mild arthritis.

C) INCORRECT:

Prednisone is a potent anti-inflammatory agent, but the patient has stable lab values and mild joint symptoms without systemic SLE exacerbation. The patient is reluctant to increase corticosteroids due to weight gain concerns. Long-term high-dose corticosteroids carry risks like metabolic disturbances and osteoporosis, making them unsuitable for mild, chronic articular involvement.

D) INCORRECT:

Mycophenolate mofetil is used for severe organ involvement in SLE, such as lupus nephritis. The patient has isolated joint symptoms with stable systemic findings. Mycophenolate's adverse effects, like gastrointestinal disturbances and bone marrow suppression, outweigh its benefits for mild, non-deforming joint involvement.

questions.text:
A 2-day-old newborn is brought to the pediatrician for a routine check-up. The mother reports the baby has been feeding every 2 to 3 hours but seems less active than expected. The mother has experienced intermittent malar rashes and joint swelling for several years but was never evaluated for any chronic condition. The baby's birth weight was at the 50th percentile. No murmurs are detected (see report).

Heart rate
55 beats per minute

Electrocardiogram: Regular P waves and a slower, unrelated QRS rate
Which maternal factor is most likely responsible for this neonate’s cardiac conduction findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anti-acetylcholine receptor autoantibodies are linked to myasthenia gravis and can cause transient neonatal myasthenia, not cardiac conduction abnormalities. The neonate's complete heart block is associated with maternal antibodies targeting ribonucleoproteins, such as anti-Ro SSA, seen in conditions like systemic lupus erythematosus.

B) INCORRECT:

Anti-double-stranded DNA autoantibodies are associated with systemic lupus erythematosus and are used to monitor disease activity. However, they do not cause neonatal cardiac conduction abnormalities. The conduction defect results from antibodies that cross the placenta and target cardiac tissue, such as anti-Ro SSA autoantibodies, not anti-double-stranded DNA antibodies.

C) INCORRECT:

Anti-cardiolipin autoantibodies are associated with antiphospholipid syndrome, leading to placental thrombosis and fetal loss, not cardiac conduction defects. Neonatal heart block is mediated by antibodies against SSA/Ro or SSB/La antigens, causing inflammation and fibrosis in the fetal conduction system.

D) CORRECT:

Neonatal complete heart block is caused by the transplacental transfer of maternal anti-Ro SSA autoantibodies, often associated with systemic lupus erythematosus. These antibodies target fetal cardiac tissue, particularly the conduction system, leading to inflammation and fibrosis of the atrioventricular node. This results in atrioventricular dissociation, with P waves occurring independently of the slower ventricular rhythm, as seen on the electrocardiogram. The maternal history of malar rash and joint swelling suggests an undiagnosed autoimmune condition, supporting the role of anti-Ro SSA autoantibodies in congenital heart block as part of neonatal lupus syndrome.

Key learning point: Congenital heart block in neonates is often associated with maternal autoimmune conditions, particularly systemic lupus erythematosus, due to the transplacental passage of anti-Ro/SSA and anti-La/SSB antibodies.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman with systemic lupus erythematosus presents to the Outpatient Clinic. She has been on mycophenolate mofetil for the past two years to maintain remission, with stable disease and no recent flares. She has normal renal function and no current proteinuria. She plans to conceive within the next six months and is concerned about potential medication risks (see lab results).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Hemoglobin
130 g/L
120 - 160 g/L


WBC
7.0 x 109/L
4.5 - 10.5 x 109/L


Creatinine
80 μmol/L
44 - 115 μmol/L



Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in managing her immunosuppressive therapy?

choices.text: Continue mycophenolate mofetil at the current dose
Introduce azathioprine and discontinue mycophenolate mofetil
Switch from mycophenolate mofetil to methotrexate

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although mycophenolate mofetil effectively maintains SLE remission, it is teratogenic, associated with congenital malformations and pregnancy loss. Continuing it poses significant risks for a woman planning pregnancy. Guidelines recommend discontinuing it and switching to a safer alternative to minimize fetal exposure.

B) CORRECT:

Mycophenolate mofetil is contraindicated in women planning pregnancy due to its high teratogenic risk. Azathioprine, however, is safer during pregnancy and effective in maintaining remission in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). It has limited transplacental passage, reducing fetal exposure. Transitioning to azathioprine aligns with recommendations for managing SLE in pregnancy, balancing disease control with fetal safety.

Key learning point: In women with SLE planning pregnancy, mycophenolate mofetil should be discontinued due to teratogenicity, and azathioprine is a safer alternative for immunosuppression during pregnancy.

C) INCORRECT:

Methotrexate is contraindicated in pregnancy due to its teratogenic effects, including neural tube defects. Switching from mycophenolate mofetil to methotrexate does not address teratogenic concerns. Safer alternatives, like azathioprine, are preferred for women planning conception.

D) INCORRECT:

Discontinuing all immunosuppressive therapy in SLE increases the risk of disease flares, which can lead to maternal and fetal complications during pregnancy. While mycophenolate mofetil should be stopped due to teratogenicity, maintaining some form of immunosuppression, such as azathioprine, is essential for disease control.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman presents with persistent polyarticular joint pain and swelling for the past two months, predominantly involving her knees and wrists, to the Outpatient Clinic. She has a three-year history of systemic lupus erythematosus and has been on a stable low-dose of oral prednisolone for one year. She complains of steroid-related weight gain and mood changes. Examination shows tender synovitis of both knees and wrists. Laboratory testing shows elevated inflammatory markers but no evidence of renal or neurological involvement.
Which of the following interventions is most appropriate to control her arthritis while reducing long-term glucocorticoid exposure?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) with persistent polyarticular arthritis, low-dose methotrexate serves as a disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD) that reduces joint inflammation by interfering with nucleotide synthesis and modulating inflammatory cytokines. This approach alleviates arthritis symptoms and allows for reduced glucocorticoid use, addressing steroid-related side effects like weight gain and mood changes. Methotrexate is effective for musculoskeletal involvement in SLE without significant organ-threatening complications.

Key learning point: In SLE patients with active polyarthritis, acute management often involves glucocorticoids like prednisolone, and methotrexate can be used as a DMARD to control symptoms and reduce glucocorticoid dependency.

B) INCORRECT:

Cyclophosphamide is reserved for severe SLE manifestations, such as proliferative lupus nephritis or central nervous system involvement. It is not appropriate for isolated polyarticular arthritis due to its significant toxicity risks, including gonadal toxicity and bone marrow suppression. Less aggressive, steroid-sparing DMARDs are more suitable for this patient's condition.

C) INCORRECT:

Increasing prednisolone could worsen steroid-related side effects like weight gain and mood changes. Long-term glucocorticoid use risks include osteoporosis and hyperglycemia. A steroid-sparing approach is more appropriate for isolated articular symptoms without major organ involvement.

D) INCORRECT:

High-dose IV methylprednisolone is used for severe SLE flares with organ involvement, not for chronic polyarticular arthritis. This patient already experiences steroid-related side effects, and pulse therapy would increase glucocorticoid exposure without addressing the need for a steroid-sparing strategy.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman at 12 weeks’ gestation presents to the Outpatient Clinic for a routine prenatal visit. She has long-standing systemic lupus erythematosus controlled on low-dose prednisone and hydroxychloroquine. She recently stopped taking all medications for the last two days after reading online about potential medication harm to her fetus. Her vital signs are stable, and she has no new symptoms.
Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation regarding her hydroxychloroquine therapy?

choices.text: Continue hydroxychloroquine at the same dose

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Methotrexate is contraindicated in pregnancy due to its teratogenic effects, including the risk of congenital malformations. Hydroxychloroquine is preferred for managing SLE in pregnancy due to its safety and effectiveness in preventing disease flares.

B) INCORRECT:

High-dose corticosteroids are reserved for active SLE flares and can cause adverse effects like gestational diabetes and hypertension. This patient has stable disease on low-dose prednisone and hydroxychloroquine, which provide balanced disease management during pregnancy.

C) INCORRECT:

Discontinuing immunomodulatory therapy in SLE increases the risk of disease flares, which can lead to complications like miscarriage and preterm birth. Hydroxychloroquine and low-dose prednisone are safe and essential for maintaining disease remission during pregnancy.

D) CORRECT:

Hydroxychloroquine is safe during pregnancy and crucial for controlling systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). It reduces the risk of disease flares, which can lead to adverse maternal and fetal outcomes. Maintaining hydroxychloroquine therapy is associated with lower rates of pregnancy loss, preterm birth, and neonatal complications. It may also reduce the risk of neonatal lupus and congenital heart block. Continuing hydroxychloroquine at the same dose optimizes maternal and fetal health.

Key learning point: Hydroxychloroquine is safe to continue during pregnancy in patients with SLE to prevent disease flares.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old woman presents with a 2-week history of swelling in her feet and ankles and dark-colored urine.
